filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of Blake's 22 engraved Illustrations of the Book of Job. This work is generally considered Blake's masterpiece in traditional line engraving, as well as the culmination of his long pictorial engagement with the Book of Job. His first series of 19 water colors illustrating Job were commissioned c. 1805-06 by his chief patron, Thomas Butts. These are available in the Archive in Preview (see description below). In 1821, Blake and his new patron John Linnell borrowed this Butts set of designs. Linnell traced the series and Blake colored them. Blake also added two more compositions to this later group and added versions of these same compositions to the earlier series, so that both sets now have 21 designs. The Linnell set led directly to his commissioning of the engravings, as set forth in a contract dated 25 March 1823. Blake began the project by executing a series of 21 reduced pencil sketches of the central designs for transfer to the copperplates. According to John Linnell, the border designs, unique to the engraved series, were a last-minute addition. Blake also added a title page, perhaps late in the production process. Although 21 of the plates bear 1825 imprints (the second plate was mistakenly dated 1828), Linnell's account books show that the engravings were not published until March 1826.
The copy reproduced in the Archive is from the first printing on laid India paper with the word Proof appearing lower right on all but the title page. Also included, as the first item, is a copy of the original letterpress cover label for the Job engravings. Our complete transcription of all engraved texts on each plate is the first to be published in any form. Both these inscribed texts and the designs are fully searchable.
At present the Archive contains 48 copies of 18 of Blake's 19 illuminated books, all fully searchable. In addition to the Butts set of Job designs, Blake's illustrations to Milton's "L'Allegro" and "Il Penseroso" are also available in Preview, our mode of presentation that provides all the features of the Archive except Image Search and Inote (our image annotation program). In the near future we expect to release a much-anticipated electronic edition of Jerusalem Copy E, and further supplementary materials, including a biography and glossary and more drawings and prints in Preview, including the Job pencil sketches noted above.
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible through the continuing support of the Institute for Advanced Technology in the Humanities at the University of Virginia, by a major grant from the Preservation and Access Division of the National Endowment for the Humanities, by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, and by the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Seven winged angels, perhaps representing the seven days of creation in Genesis, hover in a semi-circle below the inscribed words. Reading from top left to top right, we see an angel from behind, his hair long and his wings above his head with the tips touching; an angel with long hair, facing forward, holding a scroll and possibly a writing instrument of some sort; an angel with short curly hair hovering horizontally and facing forward, holding a scroll and quill; an angel with long hair, hovering horizontally, seen from behind but his face turned so that we see it in profile, possibly looking up; a long-haired angel facing forward with the top of a scroll just left of his right arm; a long-haired angel with wings raised, face seen in three-quarter view; and finally a long-haired angel facing forward, his wings raised with the tips touching. We see only the heads and upper bodies of six of the angels; only the lowest angel's full body is pictured, legs extended to the right. A horizontal line appears between the first and second lines of text; the decorative letter forms of several words suggest leaves or vines, particularly in the word "JOB."

component.illusobjdesc: In the semi-circle of hovering angels, the winged angel top left is seen from behind. His long hair falls over his back; his raised wings touch at their tips.

In the semi-circle of hovering angels, the winged angel second from top left faces forward. His hair is long; he holds a scroll and perhaps a writing instrument of some sort (as suggested by the very slight, elongated form just above his right hand adjacent to the left side of the scroll). He may be writing (or have just left off writing, given the position of the instrument).

In the semi-circle of hovering angels, the winged angel third from top left faces forward. His hair is short and perhaps a bit curly. He holds a scroll and a quill pen; he may be writing (or just left off writing, given the position of the quill). Although most of his body is covered by his companion to the right, his body must be horizontal.

In the semi-circle of hovering angels, the lowest winged angel is seen from behind, but with his face turned upward and to the right in profile. His hair is long; his legs are together and extend horizontally to the right.

In the semi-circle of hovering angels, the winged angel third from top right faces forward. His hair is long; he holds a scroll, the curled end of which is visible just to the left of his right upper arm. His wings, raised to the right, touch at their tips.

In the semi-circle of hovering angels, the winged angel second from top right has long hair. His wings extend upward to the right and may touch at their tips. His body faces forward, but his head is turned partly to the left.
In the semi-circle of hovering angels, the winged angel top right faces forward. His hair is long; the tips of his raised wings touch.

desc.related: These sketches may be related to the female figure (one of Job’s daughters) kneeling to the left of Job’s wife in Object 3 of the engravings.
This sketch may be related, albeit distantly, to the foliage on the large central tree in Objects 3 and 23 of the engravings.

These sketches may be related to the dog with its head resting on a sheep in the center foreground in Object 3 of the engravings or to the dog with its head resting on the ground in the center foreground in Object 23 of the engravings.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Job, his wife, and his sons and daughters sit and kneel in attitudes of prayer before a large, central tree (perhaps an oak). Job and his wife have open books (perhaps Bibles) on their laps; all seven sons hold shepherd's crooks. The son farthest to the left also has a harp; a larger harp, a mandolin (or some such stringed instrument), a tambourine, and four horned instruments hang in the tree above the heads of Job and his wife. A musical horn dangles by the side of the son farthest to the left. Six sheep, and what may be a sheepdog, lie in the grassy foreground. Just behind the human figures is a large flock of sheep, visible left and right; behind the sheep are (from left to right) a clump of trees, a Gothic building (probably a church), a cluster of (six?) tents, and a cluster of bushes or small trees. Above the background hills and mountains are a radiant sun on the horizon (left) and a star or planet and crescent moon (right).

component.illusobjdesc: Job's wife sits on the left side of the central tree, her hands together in prayer. She is gowned and faces forward; an open book (possibly a Bible) rests on her lap. Lines on its pages indicate a text.

Job sits among his family on the right side of the central tree. He is long-haired, bearded, gowned, and faces forward. He holds an open book in his lap. Lines on its pages indicate a text. Like most of the other figures in the scene, Job may be praying.

On the far left of the group of figures is one of Job's sons. He kneels while holding a shepherd's crook. Like most of the other figures in the scene, he may be praying. A small musical horn dangles at his right thigh. He wears a long gown and his hair is short and perhaps curly. He faces half-way between forward and to the right, with his head lowered slightly. His bare right foot, and the bare heel of his left foot, are pictured.

The figure second from the left, one of Job's sons, kneels and prays, palms together. He is gowned and faces half-way between forward and to the right. His hair is short and a little curly; he holds a shepherd's crook under his left arm. His head is raised slightly.

The figure third from the left, one of Job's sons, kneels and prays, hands clasped together. He is gowned and faces half-way between forward and to the right. He is bearded and his hair is long. Although we see only the top of a shepherd's crook above his head, he may be holding it under his left arm, like his brother to the left.

We see only the bearded head and perhaps a bit of gown over the left shoulder of Job's son fourth from the left. He faces forward and to the right. He is very probably kneeling, like his brothers, and may be praying. Although we see only the top of a shepherd's crook above his head, he may be holding it under his left arm, like his two brothers to the left.

One of Job's daughters kneels in prayer between the group of four brothers on the left and Job's wife. She wears a long gown; her hair is long and may in part be drawn back into a bun. Her body faces to the right, but her head is turned toward us and slightly down. Her eyes may be closed, or at least looking sharply downward. Her bare feet are prominent.

One of Job's daughters kneels between her parents in the center of the design. Like her sister to the left, she may be praying. She is gowned and has long hair. We see her from behind, but her face is turned in profile to the left and slightly down. Her bare feet are prominent.

One of Job's daughters kneels just to the right of Job and left of the group of three son's on the right. Like her sisters, she may be praying. She is gowned and has her arms crossed over her breast; the fingers of her right hand are spread apart slightly. She faces part-way between forward and to the right; her head is tilted slightly down. Her long (?) hair is gathered into a bun; her bare left foot is prominent.

One of Job's sons kneels in prayer, palms together, far right in the group of figures. He is gowned; his hair is short and curly. He holds a shepherd's crook, apparently between his bent arms; a lyre dangles below his left arm. He faces to the left and his bare left foot is prominent.

One of Job's sons kneels in prayer, hands clasped together, second from the right in the group of figures. He is gowned, bearded, and his hair is short and curly. He faces half-way between forward and to the left and holds his shepherd's crook under his right arm.

One of Job's sons kneels third from the right in the group of figures. He is gowned, bearded, and has long hair. Like his brothers to the right, he may be praying. He faces half-way between forward and to the left and holds his shepherd's crook with both hands.

The group of foreground animals includes, left to right, a ram, three sheep, a dog with its muzzle resting on one of the sheep, the hindquarters of a sheep apparently facing right, a ram, and perhaps the back of a final sheep. All are lying prone; the dog, the sheep below his head, and the ram on the right have their eyes closed and may be sleeping. The rams display looped and spiral-like horns.
A small mound of earth appears below the central tree and kneeling figures.
The foreground landscape would appear to be covered with tufts of grass, particularly prominent below the sheep.
The upper center of the composition is anchored by a large and leafy tree, probably an oak.
A large flock of sheep is pictured in the middle distance on the left side of the composition. They are all standing, some with heads down to eat the grass.

A large flock of sheep is pictured in the middle distance on the right side of the composition. Several in the front rank are lying prone. Third from the front is a ram with twisted, spiral-like horns. The sheep second from the front has its eyes closed and may be sleeping.
A small clump of leafy trees appears in the background between the left edge of the inner design and the large gothic building.

A large Gothic building, perhaps a church, appears in the background on the left. It is decorated with a tower, spires, and several pointed arches, the last feature probably representing both a doorway (front middle facade of the building) and windows. The building is probably made of stone.
Several tents, perhaps six in all, appear in the middle distance right of the large tree.
A cluster of leafy plants, probably bushes or small trees, appears between the sheep and the tents along the right margin of the central design.
A line of hills, with a larger mountain on the right, define the horizon.
A rising or setting sun appears just above the horizon. Its radiance forms spiky beams of light.
A crescent moon appears in the sky on the right. As in Coleridge's "Dejection: An Ode," the dark portion of the moon is rimmed with a line of reflected light.
A star or planet (possibly Venus, given the rising or setting sun far left) appears above the mountain peak left of the crescent moon.

A group of seven musical instruments hang in the tree above the heads of Job and his wife. They are, from left to right, a horn with a looped, spiral-like body, a tambourine, a mandolin (or some such stringed instrument), a large triangular harp, two horns, and a trumpet.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Bottom right is an ox or horned cow; its opposite creature on the right is a horned ram. Both are lying prone; a few tufts of grass grow on the ground right of the ox. An altar stands, lower center, on a mound or plinth; its upper corners are decorated with the (sculpted) heads of horned rams. Flames and smoke arise from the top of the altar, apparently from a burnt sacrifice. The smoke apparently reaches into the upper reaches of the border, forming the cloud-outlines above the outline of a pointed tent that forms, in effect, an inner border for the central design.

component.illusobjdesc: An ox or horned cow lies prone in the lower left corner of the border design. We see only its head, right foreleg, and a bit of its chest.
A ram lies prone in the lower right corner of the border design. We see only its head, one loop and spiral-like horn, a bit of the creature's chest, and its left foreleg.
A (stone?) altar, apparently bearing a burning sacrifice, appears lower center on a plinth or low mound of earth. A text is written on the side of the altar.
A few tufts of grass appear right of the ox or cow in the lower left corner of the border design.

The upper right and left corners of the altar, bottom center, are decorated with the heads of rams. Their horns are looped and spiral-like. They may be sculpted in stone—or the skulls of once living animals previously sacrificed on the altar. The heads face slightly downward.
Flames of a sacrifice rise above the altar. Cloud-like outlines of smoke extend to the right and left.
The cloud-like outlines in the upper reaches of the border design may be extensions of the smoke below the central design. These clouds bear texts.
The outline of a tent, pointed at the top, forms an inner container or border above and on both sides of the central design.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Job sits with his family lower center, holding a book or tablet and gesturing with his right hand. His wife is to the left, holding on open book on her lap. Six of Job's children sit, lie, and stand on the right; one holds a scroll, two others hold opened books. The seated figures are supported by an odd bench with gothic tracery and niches. The most prominent niche contains a sleeping dog; to the right are books. Two winged angels hover lower left; both hold scrolls. Behind the family group are three trees with vines entwined around their trunks. A flock of sheep grazes in the left middle distance; behind them is a mountain peak. Another complex figure group appears in the heavens above, partly contained within cloud bands left and right. At the top sits God with a halo behind his head and upper body and an open book on his lap. He points downward with his right index finger to Satan, who hovers, striding vigorously to the left, in flames. Also in the fire are the faces of Job and his wife. Four angels hover on the left side of the group; one deposits a scroll before God's throne-like chair, another holds an open book. These figures are balanced by a group of five on the right, including another angel placing a scroll before God and another holding a scroll.

component.illusobjdesc: The foreground is grassy.

Job sits with his family lower center. His hair and beard are long; his bare left foot appears beneath the ruffled hem of his gown. He faces forward, but his head is turned slightly to the left. He holds a book or tablet (bearing lines of a text) between his left hand and left knee. With his right hand he gestures downward and to the right, fingers spread. His head and eyes are turned slightly upward.
Job holds a book or tablet bearing lines of a text.

Job's wife sits to the left of her husband. She is gowned and her hair is long. She faces forward, but with her head turned slightly to the right and downward, with eyes looking slightly downward. She holds an open book on her lap.
Job's wife holds an open book on her lap. A few lines on one of its pages suggests the presence of a text.

Two winged and youthful angels hover lower left in the central design. The front-most angel is gowned and holds a scroll. His hair is long; his body faces forward but his head is turned in profile to the right.
The two winged and youthful angels, lower left, hold scrolls in their hands.

Two winged and youthful angels hover lower left in the central design. The rear angel, almost covered by his companion, is gowned and holds a scroll. His hair is long; his body faces forward but his head is turned slightly to the right.

One of Job's youthful sons sits, half-reclining, just to the right of his father. His hair is short and curly. He faces forward, with his head turned to the left and slightly down. He is nude except for a crown and a bit of drapery covering his lap. He holds a scroll in both hands. His right leg is bent at the knee before him, his left leg extended to the right. His bare feet are clearly pictured.

One of Job's daughters is the second figure to the right of her father. She is seated and half-reclining, with her legs extended to the right (her left leg may be crossed at the ankle behind her right leg). Like her brother to the left, she wears a crown. She is gowned, and faces forward with her head turned slightly to the left. Her hair is long and curly. She holds the shoulder of the young boy to the right; the fingers of her left hand are spread apart. Her left foot is clearly pictured.

A young boy appears as the third figure to the right of Job. We see only his head (facing forward and slightly to the left) and upper torso, which is undraped. He is probably sitting, like the two figures to the left.

A youthful and nude male stands, facing left, as the third figure from the right in the foreground of the central design. His right leg is extended backward, with his right foot resting on tiptoe and supported by a part of the bench (?) behind him. His hair is long and he holds a partly opened book in his hands.

Two figures are pictured just to the left of the right margin of the central design. We see only the head of the one furthest to the left. The figure is probably male, with curly hair. He faces half-way between forward and to the left, with his eyes and head turned slightly downward. He may be reading the book held by his companion to the right.

Two figures are pictured just to the left of the right margin of the central design. We see only the left arm and hand, upper torso, and head of the young female figure closest to the right margin. Her hair is long. She is gowned and holds (and possibly reads from) an open book before her. Her body faces forward, with her head tilted down and to the left.
A bit of vegetation, perhaps bushes or the tops of distant and leafy trees, appears in the middle distance between the left margin of the central design and the left side of the hovering angels.
A flock of sheep graze on the grass between the hovering angels and Job's wife in the near middle-distance.
A hill or distant mountain is pictured above the sheep who graze between the hovering angels and Job's wife.
Horizontal hatching lines in the sky above Job and his family hint at clouds.
Job and four members of his family sit on an odd bench- like seat that includes niches and pseudo-gothic tracery.
The bench on which Job and four members of his family sit includes a niche just right of Job's legs. A dog, lying prone and facing left, sleeps in this niche.
At least one, and perhaps several, books rest within the niche left of the lower right margin of the central design.
Three trees, each bearing at least a few leaves, appear in the middle distance to the right of Job. Each has an entwined vine around its trunk. The vine on the right-most tree bears two leaves.

Cloud bands, left and right, define the interior spaces of the upper part of the composition. The clouds on the left extend downward to the area between the left margin of the central design and the hovering angels left of Job and his family; they also curve to the right and form a cloud background for Satan's right foot.

God, enthroned, sits at the highest point in the central design. A halo frames his head and upper body; his hair and beard are long. Oddly spiky tufts of hair project like rays from his head. His bare right foot appears beneath the hem of his gown. He holds (with his left hand) an open book on his lap; he points downward with his right hand and extended index finger.
Lines of radiance extend from the halo around God's head and upper body.
God sits, enthroned, on a chair or seat, apparently made of stone. It is raised on a plinth or on two or three steps.
Four angels hover to the left of God. The upper-most angel faces right and slightly down. We see only his face and torso; his hair is curly. He is probably gowned and may be bowing before God.
Four angels hover to the left of God. The angel second from the top faces right and slightly down. He is probably gowned; his hair is short and curly. He may be bowing before God.

Four angels hover to the left of God. The angel third from the top faces right and slightly down, with his body facing forward. He is gowned; his hair is longish. His arms are reaching out horizontally, relative to his body. He is bowing before God and has just offered, with fingers spread, a scroll before God's throne. His bare feet are prominent.
Four angels hover to the left of God. A scroll with lines of text appears just below the extended hands of the angel third from the top.

Four angels hover to the left of God. The lower-most angel is gowned and faces to the right. His body is slightly twisted away from the viewer; his legs are crossed at the knees. His hair is short. He holds a partly opened book in his right hand.
Four angels hover to the left of God. The lower-most angel is gowned and faces to the right. He holds a book showing several separated leaves.
We see the head of Job’s wife just below Satan’s extended left arm. She faces forward and to the right; her mouth is open and her long hair merges with the surrounding flames.

Satan hovers in flames in the middle of the central design. He strides energetically to the left, but with his head twisted up and to the right to look at God. His hair is short and curly, his nude body youthful and muscular. His arms are raised, bent at the elbows, with the fingers of both hands spread apart. His mouth is open and he may be speaking. His bare feet are prominent.
We see the head of Job just below Satan's extended right arm. His long hair and beard merge with the surrounding flames.
Satan hovers before flames in the middle of the central design, with one tongue of fire extending over his right thigh. The faces of Job and his wife appear within the flames.

Five angels hover right of God and Satan. We see only the head and back of the upper-most figure. Like his companions, he may be gowned; his hair is short and curly. He faces down and to the left and may be bowing before God.

Five angels hover right of God and Satan. We see only a part of the head and body of the figure second from the top. Like his companions, he appears to be gowned; his hair is fairly long. He faces down and to the left and may be bowing before God.

Five angels hover right of God and Satan. The third figure from the top faces down and to the left, with his head raised and his lower body turned toward the viewer; he may be bowing before God. He is gowned and has long hair. His legs are together and his bare feet are prominent. He reaches forward to the left, holding a scroll in his left hand. He may be about to place the scroll before God's throne.

Five angels hover right of God and Satan. The lowest two in the group are clustered together, with the rear-most figure half covered by his companion. This rear figure faces forward and to the left, but his upper body must be twisted to the right, given the fact that his hands (fingers slightly spread) are reaching to the right. His hair is short and curly; his legs are extended to the right and his bare feet are prominent. There is no evidence of clothing.

Five angels hover right of God and Satan. The lowest two in the group are clustered together. The front-most figure faces forward and down and to the left, with his upper body twisted at the waist. His hair is short and curly; there is no evidence of clothing. His legs are extended to the right and slightly crossed at the calves. He holds a scroll in both hands.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The side borders are dominated by Gothic tracery. In its lower reaches, it is intertwined to form niches; above, on both sides, are the beginnings of an arch. In the left margin, the niches contain (bottom to top) a peacock; two birds sitting at the edge of a birdbath; a single bird, possibly disporting in a birdbath; a column of clouds or smoke; and at least four hovering figures, probably angels, with their heads lowered. Just above them is a Gothic arch and, trailing upward and to the right, a slender vine with loops. In the top margin are two cloud bands and rays of light. The niches in the right margin contain (bottom to top) a bird, probably a parrot; a bird in a birdbath; another bird in a birdbath; a column of flames; and at least two hovering figures, probably angels, with their heads lowered. Above them is a Gothic arch and (as in the companion design in the left margin) a slender vine that curls upward (with one loop) and to the left. The lower margin is dominated by two fences, probably made of wood, with some bushes, or the outline of bushy hills, in the background. Several creatures appear in this lower design; these are, left to right, a gowned shepherd, seen from behind, wearing a broad-brimmed hat, and holding a crook; a flock of sheep, with only one clearly pictured; a sleeping dog; a horned ram with a flock of sheep to the right behind the fence; and an aged, bearded shepherd, with hat and crook.

component.illusobjdesc: Two cloud bands, both with texts, and associated beams of light adorn the upper border design.

The border designs in the left and right margins are dominated by intertwined Gothic tracery. These form niches, lower right and left, and the beginning of arches at the top on both sides. Their intertwined pattern suggests the Tree of Jesse motif. Indeed, the configurations of the individual extensions of the tracery suggest that it is made of wood—possibly living wood.
A bird, probably a peacock with a long tail and crest, is perched in the niche in the lower left. The bird's body faces forward, with its head turned to the right.

In the second niche from the bottom in the left marginal design, two birds perch, wings raised, on the rim of a birdbath. The next niche above shows another bird with raised wings, disporting in a birdbath.
In the second and third niches from the bottom in the left marginal design are two birdbaths, both in use.
A column of smoke or clouds rises in the niche with angels in the left border design.

Four figures, perhaps angels although wingless, hover two- by-two on each side of the column of clouds or smoke in the left border design. The front-most figure on the left faces right and down, with his (?) head lowered and his right arm bent upward to or toward his head. His right hand may be touching his face. He is probably gowned and may wear a hood that obscures his facial features. The figure behind is minimally sketched in outline; we see only his (?) head.
A triformed Gothic arch decorates the upper termination of the niche with angels in the left border design.

A slender vine curls upward from the Gothic tracery in the left border design, extends with loops through the inner border of the central design, and reaches to the right along the base of the cloud outline in the upper border design. Just to the left of the lower reaches of this vine, and just above the triform Gothic arch, are a few lines that hint at two more vines (although these may be part of the architectural decoration).
A triformed Gothic arch decorates the upper termination of the niche with angels in the right border design.

A slender vine curls upward from the Gothic tracery in the right border design, extends with a loop through the inner border of the central design, and reaches to the left along the base of the cloud outline in the upper border design.

Two figures, perhaps angels although wingless, hover on each side of the flames in the right border design. The figure on the left faces right and down, with his (?) head lowered and his right arm bent upward to or toward his chest. He is probably gowned and his hair may be long (like his companion's).

Two figures, perhaps angels although wingless, hover on each side of the flames in the right border design. The figure on the right faces left and down, with his (?) head lowered. He is probably gowned and has long hair. His left arm appears to be bent upward at the elbow.
A column of flames ascends in the niche also containing two angels in the right border design.
Two birds disport, each in its own birdbath, in the two niches below the one containing the column of flames in the right border design.
The lowest niche in the right border design, just above a shepherd, contains a perching bird, perhaps a parrot of some sort. The bird's body faces forward, with its head turned to the left.

The bottom marginal design is dominated (except for a break in the middle) by a post and rail fence, probably made of wood. Behind and above the fence is a squiggly line that may be distant hills topped with trees.
Behind and above the fence in the lower border design is a squiggly line that may be a hedge or the tops of distant trees on a hill.

A gowned shepherd, or perhaps a shepherdess, stands lower left behind the fence. We see the figure from behind. She or he wears a broad-brimmed hat and holds a shepherd's crook in her/his right hand. The right arm is bent upward.
A few sketchy lines suggest a flock of sheep behind the fence. The head and leg of one sheep, lying prone, is clearly pictured just to the right of the end of the left section of the fence.
A sleeping dog lies prone in the gap in the fence. His body faces left, with his head twisted back to the right.

A few lines suggest a flock of sheep behind the fence on the right. The head of a ram, with a looped horn, is clearly visible just to the left of the left end of the fence. He is lying prone and facing left.
An aged shepherd with long beard and hair stands lower right. He wears a broad-brimmed hat and holds a shepherd's crook. He wears a gown and faces to the left. His left arm is bent upward.

desc.objtitle: Job's Sons and Daughters Overwhelmed by Satan, Object 5 (Bentley 421.4)

illustration.illusobjdesc: The central design shows the destruction of Job's family at the hands of Satan. The background is filled with dark flames and, at the top, bolts of lightning. Below are falling architectural elements, including at least two columns, and steps. On and about these steps are, just above the bottom margin, a gowned female lying supine, perhaps dead, with a lyre at her left hand and a tambourine at her feet. In the near foreground on the right is a nude male in an upside-down cruciform posture, with large plates and vessels below him. Another upside-down figure hangs just left of the lower right margin. The other figures in the lower half of the design are, from left to right, a group of three females clearly terrified (we see only their heads and gesturing arms and hands); two females reaching (for succor?) toward the male to the right; a large central nude male (whose posture, reversed, suggests that of Laocon in the famous classical sculpture) with a child on his left shoulder; and a group of five females below the central male, all with upraised arms. Above, a very dark Satan grins in terrible pleasure as he rains fire on his victims from his outstretched hands. He is half-kneeling, legs crossed, on stony blocks; his bat-like wings dominate the top of the design. A parodic and spiky halo frames his head.

component.illusobjdesc: The background of the central design is filled with dark flames.
Bolts of lightning appear along the top margin of the design and extend downward in the left and right margins.

Satan, in the top third of the design, half-kneels on a large block, probably of stone. Another such block appears just right of his right foot. These are probably broken pieces of the house of Job's eldest son. They may be falling on the figures below.

Two falling columns, probably made of stone, indicate the destruction of the house of Job's eldest son. The upper-most column has a simple classical capital. The block under the lower column fragment, and just left of the right margin of the central design, may also be a broken column.

The figures in the lower part of the central image are displayed on or about a series of (stone?) steps rising from left to right. In the lower right corner are another (two?) steps, visible just right of the upside-down figure. The block near the right margin, just below the lower falling column, may be part of the steps. These are probably all fragments of what was once stairs.
At least two large plates or platters, a bowl or goblet, and a vase fill the space beneath the outstretched arms of the upside-down figure in the lower right corner of the central design.
A tambourine rests beneath the feet of the supine woman just above the bottom margin of the central design. A lyre rests under her left hand.

A gowned young woman—a member of Job's family now being destroyed—lies supine just above the lower margin of the central design. Her long hair is spread out on the ground, her legs are together and her left arms stretched out along her body. A tambourine rests beneath her prominent bare feet; a lyre lies below her left hand. Her head is bent back and her eyes are closed; she may be dead. Her feet are prominent.

A youthful male nude hangs upside down in the lower right corner of the central design. His long hair spreads out beneath his head. His eyes maybe be closed, or perhaps open with a blank stare; he may be dead. His arms, raised at 135 degrees relative to his body, suggest a cruciform position. His lower legs twist to the left.

A youthful male (?) nude hangs upside down in the lower right corner of the central design, just to the right of the more prominent upside-down figure. It is difficult to discern any details about his posture. His mouth is slightly open; his eyes are blank or closed. He may be dead or (if we can accurately read his facial expression) undergoing the agonies of death.

A group of three youthful (nude?) females in the middle distance are the left-most figures in the composition. We see only their heads, arms, and upper bodies. The figure farthest to the left twists her head up and to the right. Her right arm is bent over her head; her left arm is slightly bent and raised just above the horizontal. The palms of both hands are vertical, fingers slightly spread. Her mouth is open; she may be crying out in pain or terror. Her hair is probably short and may be curly.

A group of three youthful (nude?) females in the middle distance are the left-most figures in the composition. We see only their heads, arms, and upper bodies. The figure second from the left faces forward with her head slightly raised. Her hair is long and her mouth is slightly open; her eyes may be raised heavenward. She appears to be praying in her terror, given the position of her hands in front of her chest, fingers knit together.

A group of three youthful (nude?) females in the middle distance are the left-most figures in the composition. We see only their heads, arms, and upper bodies. The figure third from the left faces forward with her head twisted up and to the right. Her hair is long and her mouth is open in an expression of pain or terror. She raises her bent left arm over her head; the fingers of her left hand are spread apart.

Two young, long-haired, and gowned (or at least partly gowned) females are pictured immediately to the left of the central male figure. They both raise their arms toward the male, the fingers of their hands spread apart. Their eyes are raised and their mouths are open in expressions of terror or pain as they seek help from the male. The front-most figure in this group faces to the right, with her head twisted up and a bit forward. Her right leg is bent beneath her as she kneels on a step; her left leg is extended backward. Her right upper arm is grasped by the central male. Both feet are on tiptoe.

Two young, long-haired, and gowned (or at least partly gowned) females are pictured immediately to the left of the central male figure. They both raise their arms toward the male, the fingers of their hands spread apart. Their eyes are raised and their mouths are open in expressions of terror or pain as they seek help from the male. The more distant figure in this group faces to the right, with her head twisted up and a bit forward. Her right leg is extended backward. Like her companion, she may by kneeling (or half-kneeling) on a step.

A gowned female, with left arm raised vertically and the fingers of her left hand spread apart, appears between the central male's right leg and the steps just to the right. We see only her head, upper body, and raised arm and hand. She faces forward, mouth open. Her expression suggests some mixture of pain and terror.

A group of four (nude?) females are pictured below the left foot of the central male figure. They all reach upward, as though seeking aid from the male. The left-most figure is seen from behind, her head turned upward. Her long hair streams to the right; her arms are raised vertically. The fingers of her right hand are spread apart. We see only her head, upper body, and raised arm.

A group of four (nude?) females are pictured below the left foot of the central male figure. They all reach upward, as though seeking aid from the male. The figure second from the left in this group is seen from behind, her (?) head turned upward and her body twisted away from us. Her arms are raised vertically, with the fingers of her hands spread slightly apart. Her hair may be curly.

A group of four (nude?) females are pictured below the left foot of the central male figure. They all reach upward, as though seeking aid from the male. The figure third from the left in this group is seen from behind, her (?) head turned upward. Her arms are raised vertically, as she grasps two steps. She may be trying to climb upward. Her hair may be curly.

A group of four (nude?) females are pictured below the left foot of the central male figure. They all reach upward, as though seeking aid from the male. The right-most figure in this group faces forward with open mouth. Her visage suggests pain or terror. Her arms are raised vertically, with the fingers of her hands spread apart. Her hair may be curly. She may be wearing a crown or hat of some sort, or her hair is elaborately braided.

A youthful and muscular male dominates the center of the lower half of the central design. He stands and faces forward, with his left leg bent sharply at the knee to position his foot on a raised step. His right leg is extended to the left. He may be attempting to climb the steps to the right. His upper body and neck are twisted to the left; he may be looking at the females to the left. His posture echoes that of Laocoön, reversed, in the famous classical sculpture group. He is nude except for a bit of drapery that extends along the right side of his chest and covers his genitals. He extends his right arm downward to grasp the upper arm of the female to the left. His left arm is bent upward to hold a child sitting on his left shoulder. The fingers of his left hand are spread slightly apart. Both feet are on tiptoe. His hair is short and curly and his mouth is open in an expression of terror.

A young male child with short curly hair sits on the shoulder of the large central male figure. We see him from behind, but his head is twisted to the left so that he faces us. His mouth is slightly open, possibly in an expression of confusion or even terror. His bent left arm reaches to the left; he appears to be grasping the hair of the large male with his left hand, curled into a fist. His feet dangle below the man's left upper arm. This child is probably nude, although a wisp of drapery appears just left of his left hip.

A nude and dark-skinned Satan with bat-like wings dominates the top of the central design. He squats, crouches, or half- kneels, with legs sharply bent, on some stony blocks, his legs crossed just above the ankles. His arms are extended half-way between the horizontal and 45 degrees, with fingers spread apart and flames issuing from his hands (palms facing down). His hair is short and a bit curly or flame-like. His head is surrounded with a halo defined along its outer rim by spiky beams of light. Satan faces forward, but with his head twisted down and to the right. A slight, and no doubt sardonic, smile indicates his pleasure in destruction.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The top border design and the top half of each side border are dominated by cloud or smoke outlines and flames. Below, on each side, from top to bottom, are scaly tails (apparently of serpents), a step, more flames or very spiky vegetation, and scorpions. The curving forms in the lower margin suggest both spiky vegetation and flames. At its left and right terminations, this motif curves over a step and joins with the flames or vegetation surrounding the scorpions.

desc.objtitle: The Messengers Tell Job of His Misfortunes, Object 6 (Bentley 421.5)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A messenger runs, left to right, toward Job and his wife to tell them of the destruction of their family at Satan's hands. He is gowned, from the waist down, and strides energetically toward the couple. Job raises his hands as if in prayer; his wife lifts her hands, interdigitated, above her head. A ram grazes far right, below the (stony?) seat or chair on which Job (and his wife?) sit. A tree, perhaps an oak, rises along the right margin and extends its branches and leaves along the top margin of the design. Two stone pillars form the background for Job and his wife; to the left are two grazing sheep and, in the background, a clump of trees. The sky above and to the left is cloudy and stormy, an echo of the emotional condition. Another messenger, perhaps nude but wearing a hat and holding a staff, strides energetically to the left in the middle background; another messenger runs on the hill in the distant background. Trees and a Gothic building, perhaps a church, are pictured in the middle distance on the far left. The foreground, raised into a mound, appears to be covered with grass and perhaps a few flowers below Job and his wife.

component.illusobjdesc: Job's wife, gowned, sits next to her husband. Her legs face to the left, but her upper body and head are twisted toward the viewer. Her hair is long; she raises her slightly-bent arms vertically, with her palms together and her fingers interlinked, perhaps in prayer. Her face seems care-worn, perhaps with a mixture of grief and despair over the news of the her family's destruction. Her breasts (as an emblem of her maternal role?) and bare left foot are prominent.
Job sits on the right. He is gowned, with his hands together in prayer and his head back so that he looks up. His long beard and hair cascade over his upper body. His bare left foot is prominent.

A youthful and muscular male messenger runs in from the left side of the central design and toward Job and his wife. He strides dramatically, legs spread; his right arm reaches back and points horizontally to the left, and his left arm is raised to the right at 135 degrees. The fingers of both hands are slightly spread apart, and the palm of his left hand faces out. His hair stands on end at the back of his head because of his onrushing speed. His mouth is slightly open; he may be speaking as he approaches. His facial features suggest a mixture of grief and fear. His gown covers his body only from the waist to just above his knees, like a skirt, but with a belt or strap looped over his left shoulder. His body faces forward, with his head turned almost completely to the right. His bare feet are prominent.

A second male messenger strides energetically to the left in the middle distance, seen between the legs of the large messenger in the foreground. He wears a hat and holds a staff, but there are no indications of clothing. His body faces left, but his head is twisted to face the viewer, or even look back to the right. Both arms are bent, his right in front of him to hold the staff, his left behind his back.

The tiny figure of a third male (?) messenger appears on the hill above the left arm of the second messenger. He faces and strides energetically to the right, with at least one arm raised at about 135 degrees.
A Gothic (stone?) building, perhaps a church, appears lower left in the middle distance of the central design. It has spires and arches, probably a door or two, and perhaps windows.
Two sheep graze in the middle distance, half their bodies covered by the stone pillar to the right.
Behind Job and his wife are two stone pillars. The shading between the two hints at a third pillar or a wall.
Job sits on a (stone?) chair. We do not see what his wife sits on; perhaps this is a bench-like seat that can accommodate two.
A ram, with a prominent and looping horn, grazes lower right. We see only the front third of his body.
The foreground rises from lower left to right to form a slight mound on which the principal figures are disposed.
The foreground is grassy, with a few small plants and lily-like flowers below Job.
A large tree, perhaps an oak, grows up the right margin of the central design and spreads its large leaves just below the top margin.
A cluster of trees appears in the center of the central design, behind the grazing sheep and the left leg of the foreground messenger.
The short engraving strokes above and on each side of the Gothic building suggest trees rather than a background hill. There may be a tree-trunk just to the left of the building.

An earthen bank descends just to the left of the messenger in the middle distance. A small shadow extends from the messenger's left foot; there may also be a much larger shadow in the foreground associated with the large messenger. Just above the bank, and below the Gothic building, may be a body of water, possibly a lake or river.
A hill or distant mountain (on which the tiny messenger runs) forms the horizon on the left side of the central design.
Dark clouds, suggesting a storm, fill the sky.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the center of the top border, we see from behind a figure with bat-like wings—probably Satan. He stands on a semi-circle (the rim of the earth?) and holds a sword in his left hand and a shield in his right hand. Beams of light radiate from him. Cloud outlines fill the rest of the top border and descend in both side borders toward flames in the lower border, where we also find (lower right) a globe with spikes (of flame?), which may be a comet or ball of lightning, and a bolt of jagged lightning. The top corners of the inner framing lines are decorated with female (?) figures. Their hair, and at least one arm of each figure, hang down the side margins.

component.illusobjdesc: In the center of the top border, we see from behind a figure with bat-like wings—probably Satan. He stands on a semi-circle (the rim of the earth?) and holds a sword in his left hand. The point of the sword touches the semi-circle; Satan may be leaning on it, as one might use a walking-stick. A shield appears just right of his right arm; it is unclear whether the shield is held in his right hand or buckled to his right arm. His right foot is on tiptoe; he appears to be bald. There is no evidence of clothing; he may be nude.
In the center of the top border, we see from behind a bat- winged figure, very probably Satan, standing on a semi-circle. This may be the rim of the earth.

Cloud outlines, bearing texts, fill the top border and descend half-way down the side borders. Given the presence of flames below, it is possible that the outer-most cloud outlines are meant to be smoke. The inner band of clouds surrounds Satan and the earth.
Beams of light radiate from the bat-winged figure of Satan.

A figure, probably female, lies on the top left corner of the inner framing lines. It would appear that her body is twisted, with her lower body lying supine and her upper body lying prone. Her legs may be crossed, one under the other; her head, long hair, and her left (?) arm dangle over the edge of the frame. A few short lines suggest that she may be gowned.
A female figure lies supine on the top right corner of the inner framing lines. Her head, long hair, and left arm dangle over the edge of the frame. A few short lines suggest that she is gowned.

Flames undulate in the lower border. Two tongues of fire reach upward on the left; one or two more arch around the lower right corner of the inner framing lines. Perhaps we are to imagine that Blake's signature, lower right, is written on the flames.

A cloud outline appears above the flames in the lower margin. A bolt of lightning shoots from it lower right. Perhaps we are to imagine that the text immediately below the central design is written on the cloud.
A bolt of lightning shoots from a cloud just below the lower right corner of the inner framing lines.
The round object lower right may be ball lightning or perhaps a comet with spiky flames.

desc.objtitle: Satan Going Forth from the Presence of the Lord and Job's Charity, Object 7 (Bentley 421.6)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Job and his wife sit side by side on a stone bench in the lower portion of the central design. Her right hand is on her breast as she leans toward her husband. Her left hand holds his right upper arm. Job holds a rectangular object, probably half a loaf of bread, in his right hand. With his left hand he gives a similar half-loaf to an old man with a crutch and a dog on a leash. Behind the recipient of Job's charity is a winged angel. Another winged angel hovers on the left. The near foreground features grass and the leaves of small plants; in the middle distance on the left is a Druid trilithon; the horizon is defined by distant mountains with clouds above. The upper portion of the central design portrays several dramatic figures, particularly Satan. He is nude, with a slight suggestions of scales over his genitals, descending dramatically to the left. He hold a vial in his right hand from which flames (?), perhaps indicative of pestilence, descend on Job. Flames rise from this vessel and extend upward right and left, with clouds on their outer margins. On the left are six hovering figures, probably angels although without wings. Their six symmetrical companions on the right are similarly arranged in the ascending flames. In the center of this oval composition, God sits on a stone throne, raised on a plinth. He leans to the left and holds a book in his right hand, a scroll in his left. A large and radiant halo surrounds his head and upper body.

component.illusobjdesc: Job sits at the center of the lower portion of the central design. He is gowned, but his bare right foot extends beyond the hem of his garment. His left leg may be crossed behind his right at the ankles. He is bearded and his hair is long. His right arm is bent, and his right hand, resting in his lap, holds half a loaf of bread; his left arm is extended horizontally and he holds in his hand another half-loaf. He gives this bread to an old man on crutches.
Job holds two half-loaves of bread; one rests in his lap, held by his right hand, the other is held in his left hand.

Job's wife sits beside him. She is gowned and has long hair. Her bare left foot is visible beneath the hem of her garment. She leans toward her husband, with her left hand, fingers spread, holding his upper left arm. Her right arm is bent, with her right hand resting on her breast.
A gowned and winged angel hovers near the lower left margin. His hands are together in prayer as he faces forward and to the right. His head and long hair are surrounded by a halo.

A gowned and winged angel hovers near the lower right margin. His hands are together in prayer, fingers slightly spread apart, as he faces forward and to the left. His hair is long; his head may be surrounded by a halo (like his companion on the left), but this may only be the upper arch of his right wing.

An old man leaning on a crutch stands facing to the left with his eyes cast down or closed. He may be blind. His left leg is bent behind his right. His hair, beard, and gown are long; his bare left foot is prominent. He apparently holds the dog's leash with his unpictured right hand; his left arm is bent at the elbow and extended to receive an object (probably a small loaf of bread) from Job. The fingers of his left hand are spread slightly apart. He may be a beggar.
A small dog, head down and perhaps sniffing the ground, appears just to the right of Job. A thin leash extends from the dog's collar toward the old man on the right.
Job and his wife sit on a bench or seat of some sort, probably made of stone.

A few plants (with spiky leaves) and grass are pictured just above the lower margin of the central design. There may be more vegetation in the middle distance, including trees or bushes on the right behind the old man with a crutch.
Hills and mountains dominate the landscape background behind Job and his wife.
A stone trilithon appears in the middle distance just to the left of Job's wife.
The hatching lines in the sky above Job and his wife hint at clouds that grow darker left and right.

God sits, enthroned, in the top center of the design. He is old and bearded, has long hair, and wears a gown. His bare feet are both prominent, particularly the right foot. He reaches down to hold a book (right hand) and a scroll (left hand). The fingers of his right hand are spread slightly apart. His left leg is slightly bent at the knee but extends downward; his right leg is bent sharply at the knee and drawn up toward his torso. He faces forward but leans to the left. A halo-like burst of radiance with beams of light forms a backdrop for his head and upper body and extends toward the circle of angels on both sides.
God holds a book in his right hand.
God holds a scroll in his left hand.
God sits, enthroned, on a chair or seat of some sort. Its rounded arms can be seen left and right of his forearms.
God's throne and both his feet rest on a three-step plinth, probably made of stone.

Satan, a youthful and nude male, hovers (or flies rapidly) beneath God. His short curly hair rises in two arcs above his forehead in a manner that suggests horns. There are slight suggestions of scales, or at least oddly roughened skin, on his lower abdomen and over his genitals. The position of his limbs suggests dramatic movement, perhaps descending or curving from right to left. He faces forward, with his head twisted upward toward God. His mouth is slightly open, as though speaking. His left leg is extended up and to the right; his right leg is bent sharply at the knee and drawn up toward his upper right thigh. His left arm, bent slightly at the elbow, is extended over his head and to the left (but raised vertically relative to his body); his right arm is extended downward but at an angle of 135 degrees relative to his torso. The palm of his left hand faces down. The fingers of his left hand are spread slightly apart. He holds a vial in his right hand from which descends either a liquid or fire. Both feet are prominent.
Satan holds a vial in his right hand. A liquid, or perhaps fire, descends from it toward Job. This may represent the diseases that will plague Job.

Satan is surrounded by flames that my be issuing from behind the vial in his right hand. Other flames back the angels surrounding God, right and left. Behind the flame are bands of clouds or possibly smoke.
Six figures, probably male angels, hover to the left of God. We see only the heads of the two uppermost figures. The one on the left has long hair, the one on the right short (?) and curly hair.

Six figures, probably male angels, hover to the left of God. We see only the head, and perhaps a bit of the right shoulder and back, of the third angel from the top, just left of the angel with a raised right hand. He has long hair and faces right.

Six figures, probably male angels, hover to the left of God. We see only the head, upper body, and raised right hand (palm out) of the fourth angel from the top, just right of the angel facing right. He has long hair and faces forward.

Six figures, probably male angels, hover to the left of God. The second angel from the bottom of the group wears a gown and is twisted to face left, forward, right, and down. Both arms are bent at the elbow with hands raised. The right hand faces palm out, the right palm up with fingers slightly spread. The figure's hair is long; the bare left foot is prominent.

Six figures, probably male angels, hover to the left of God. We see the lowest figure in the group from behind, but his body is twisted to the right and his face looks to the right. He is gowned, but with a prominent bare left foot. His hair is long and his arms are bent forward, with the palms of both hands facing out with fingers spread.
Six figures, probably male angels, hover to the right of God. We see only the heads of the two top figures. They face forward and to the left; both have long hair.

Six figures, probably male angels, hover to the right of God. We see only the head and upper body of the figure third from the top. He is gowned and has long hair. His left arm may be bent upward across, and partly wrapped around, his chest.

Six figures, probably male angels, hover to the right of God. We see only the head, upper body, and right arm of the figure fourth from the top (just slightly below and to the left of the third figure from the top). He is gowned and has long hair; he faces forward with his head turned a little downward. His right arm is bent upward across, and partly wrapped around, his chest. The fingers of his right hand are spread apart.

Six figures, probably male angels, hover to the right of God. We see the second figure from the bottom from behind, but his head is twisted down and to the left so that we see his face in left profile. He is gowned and has long hair. His legs and the lower reaches of his gown seem to merge with the surrounding flames. His hands, with fingers spread, are raised with palms out (relative to his body).

Six figures, probably male angels, hover to the right of God. We see the lowest figure from behind, but his head is twisted to the left so that we see his face in left profile. He is gowned and has long hair. His bare right foot is prominent. His arms are bent sharply upward at the elbows; his hands, with fingers spread, are raised with palms out (relative to his body).

illustration.illusobjdesc: The lower border design is dominated by flames and two undulating snakes. We see their tails entwined around thorny vines in the side margins, but the head of only one snake is pictured. The flames continue to the upper margin. In each side margin, flames (or very flame-like vines) are twisted around the thorny vines. Their intertwining creates a Tree of Jesse motif. Winged angels decorate the top corners of the inner framing lines.

component.illusobjdesc: Flames would appear to issue from the bottom center of the border design and ascend in both side borders. Tongues of flames extend toward each other in the top border. The forms intertwined with the thorny vines in each side border may also be flames—or very flame-like vines.
A thorny vine twists up the left border. It is intertwined with a flame (or a very flame-like vine) to form a Tree of Jesse motif.
A thorny vine twists up the right border. It is intertwined with a flame (or a very flame-like vine) to form a Tree of Jesse motif.

Two scaly snakes dominate the lower border design. Their tails are intertwined with the thorny vines in the left and right margins. In the lower center of the design is the head of only one snake, facing left. The creature's one visible eye seems to look upward.

A winged angel, probably male, decorates the top left corner of the inner frame. He is gowned and has flame-like hair; his large wing extends horizontally along the top edge of the frame. His right arm is bent sharply upward at the elbow and his head rests on his upraised right hand. His left arm may be drawn back, although we see only his left shoulder and a bit of the upper arm. The figure suggests melancholy touched by surprise or fear.

A winged angel, probably male, decorates the top right corner of the inner frame. He is probably gowned (or holds a cloak before him) and has flame-like hair; his large wing extends horizontally along the top edge of the frame. His left arm is bent sharply upward at the elbow and his head rests on his upraised left hand. His right arm may be under his gown or cloak and drawn up toward his neck to hold the garment. The figure suggests melancholy touched by surprise or fear.

desc.related: The very light sketch of the lowered head and back of a figure seen in profile, above and right of center on this sketchbook leaf, may be related to Job’s wife, kneeling at Job’s feet in Object 8 of the engravings, or to one of Job’s friends in Object 10 of the engravings.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Job, in his misery, lies upon a bed of straw, his head bent back, arms stiffened at his side, his palms raised with fingers spread. The rough texture of his flesh suggests the sore boils that afflict him. He rests is feet against his wife, kneeling and hunched over at his feet, her head down and in her hands in grief and despair. She is gowned; Job's loins are covered with a rough (burlap?) cloth. A triumphant Satan stands above Job, his feet resting on Job's right thigh and abdomen. Satan is nude, but we can clearly see scales on his hips, upper legs, and over his genital area. His arms are raised horizontally; four arrows descend from just behind his right hand. He holds a vial in his left hand from which spills either a liquid or flames. A (mock?) halo surrounds his head. The background is dominated by billowing clouds (of smoke?) and a sun that is rising or (more probably) setting over the ocean on the far left. Ruined walls or buildings, a broken cromlech or portal, and broken columns appear in the folds of the hills in the middle distance and background. A mountain rises in the horizon, its peak obscured by Satan's body. A few spiky plants or grass appear in the near foreground, just above the lower margin of the central design.

component.illusobjdesc: Job lies supine on a bed of straw. His body seems rigid, with his head bent back in an expression of extreme pain. His hair and beard are long; the rough texture of his flesh suggests the sore boils that plague him. His arms are at his side, with palms raised and fingers spread. He is nude except for a rough (burlap?) cloth that covers his loins. His prominent bare feet rest on the legs of his kneeling wife.
Job lies on a bed or mound of straw.

Job's wife kneels at her husband's feet, which touch her thighs. She is gowned; her hair his long. She is bent over in a contracted posture, with her head down and her face covered by her upraised hands. We see her bare right foot. Her posture suggests despair.

A muscular Satan triumphs over Job, his feet resting on Job's right thigh and abdomen. He faces forward, looking down toward Job, with legs spread apart and arms raised horizontally. His mouth is open, with the suggestion of a sardonic smile; his hair is short and curly. His head and neck are twisted downward and to the right; his torso leans to the right. He is nude, but scales are clearly pictured on his thighs, hips, and genital area. Four arrows descend from behind his raised right hand, palm out. He holds a vial in his left hand, from which descends a liquid or flames. A (mock?) halo surrounds his head.
Four arrows descend from (or from behind) Satan's raised right hand. They may emblemize the diseases that plague Job.
Satan holds in his left hand a vial from which descends a liquid or flames. These may emblemize the diseases that plague Job.
Grass or spiky plants appear in the lower margin of the central design. The mottled texture of the hills in the middle distance also suggest vegetation of some sort.
Low hills dominate the middle distance. A mountain rises on the horizon, its peak obscured by Satan's body.
A sun rises (or more probably sets) above the ocean. Beams of light and radiance fill the sky.
Billowing clouds (of smoke?) fill the sky on both sides of Satan.
A ruined wall, perhaps of a building, appears behind Job's head. Just to the left, and further in the distance, is another structure, probably also a ruin. Both are probably made of stone.

A ruined structure, possibly a (stone?) portal with post and lintel or a trilithon, appears in the middle distance just left of Satan's lower right leg. Just above, and further in the distance, are three structures, perhaps ruined walls or pillars. All are probably stone.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The top border design offers cloud outlines and two bat- winged figures, one resting on a cloud (arm raised) and one soaring in the air. Similarly bat-winged angels or devils decorate the top corners of the inner framing lines. Each holds a filament of a spider's web that descends in each side margin, with a spider at its end near the lower corners of the inner framing lines. The motifs in the lower border are, from left to right, two steps or plinths, a few tufts of grass, a broken shepherd's crook, a grasshopper, a broken pot or pitcher, more spiky grass, the head of a frog or lizard, some large spiky leaves, the rim of another pot, a large (ivy or oak?) leaf, and three thistles.

component.illusobjdesc: Two steps or plinths adorn the lower left corner of the lower border design.
The two pieces of a broken shepherd's crook appear in the lower left corner of the lower border design.
A grasshopper stands, facing right, in the lower border design.
A broken pot or pitcher is pictured in the center of the lower border design.
Spiky vegetation, perhaps grass, two very spiky (holly or thistle?) leaves, a large (oak or ivy?) leaf, and three thistle flowers adorn the right half of the lower border design.
The head of a frog (or lizard?) emerges from the vegetation in the lower border design. The webbed left foot of the creature suggests a frog rather than a lizard.
Part of a pot is pictured in the lower border design, just to the right of the head of the lizard or frog.

A spider dangles at the end of a filament of web descending down the left margin. The spider has its head down—the opposite of its companion in the right margin. Since the filament extends from back of the spider's abdomen, where the spinneret is located, it may be spinning the web.

A spider dangles at the end of a filament of web descending down the right margin. The spider has its head up—the opposite of its companion in the right margin. The spider may be climbing up the filament it has just spun.

A bat-winged angel or devil adorns the top left corner of the inner framing lines. The figure is probably male and either gowned or nude. His left arm is extended horizontally along the top framing line; his lowered right hand holds the end of a filament of a spider's web. His hair is short and may be curly. See also the companion figure at the top right corner of the inner framing lines.

A bat-winged angel or devil adorns the top right corner of the inner framing lines. The figure is probably male and either gowned or nude. His right arm is extended horizontally along the top framing line; his lowered left hand holds the end of a filament of a spider's web. His hair is short. See also the companion figure at the top left corner of the inner framing lines.

A bat-winged angel or devil sits or reclines, facing forward and to the right, on a cloud outline. He or she (note the slight suggestion of female breasts) has the right arm extended back for support; the left arm is raised vertically. The legs are crossed below the knee.

A bat-winged angel or devil soars rightward (and slightly down) through the sky. The figure's gender is uncertain. It's legs are spread slightly apart and its left arm is extended horizontally to the right (but vertically in relation to the body).
Several cloud outlines, bearing texts, are pictured in the top marginal design.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Job sits on the right in his misery, nude except for a rough (burlap?) cloth over his lap. He appears to be resting uncomfortably on a bed of straw piled into a mound (or covering a mound of earth). The rough texture of his flesh suggests the sore boils that afflict him. His expression suggests despair and pain. His head is twisted to the right, eyes looking upward (for solace?), and mouth slightly parted. His arms are bent at his side, with the fingers of his left hand spread slightly apart. His wife stands behind him, her arms sharply bent upward and her palms out (fingers spread) in an expression of despair and grief. Her head is twisted to the left and her mouth slightly parted. Job's three friends enter in a rush, arms and hands raised, on the left. Eliphaz the Temanite is the figure leading the group; his identity is made clear in Object 11 (plate numbered 9). If the friends enter in the same order as they are introduced in Job 2:11, then the next figure to the left is Bildad the Shuhite and farthest to the left is Zophar the Naamathite. Various ruined walls, buildings, and perhaps one trilithon adorn the hills in the middle distance. Other walls or pillars anchor the far right margin. The near foreground contains some grass and, lower right, some thorny vines. The mottled texture of the hills in the middle distance suggests more vegetation. A burst of light (from a setting sun?) radiates above the distant mountains.

component.illusobjdesc: Job sits on the right in his misery, nude except for a rough (burlap?) cloth over his lap. He leans back against his wife. He appears to be resting uncomfortably on a bed of straw on top of a mound (of earth?). The rough texture of his flesh suggests the sore boils that afflict him. His expression suggests despair and pain. His body faces left and forward, but his head is twisted to the right, eyes looking upward (for solace?), and mouth slightly parted. He may be speaking or crying out in pain. His arms are bent at his side, with the fingers of his left hand spread slightly apart. His right hand rests on a mound of straw or earth. His hair and beard are long; his bare feet are prominent.

Job lies on a bed of straw, apparently piled into a mound or spread over a mound of earth. There is another mound under his right hand; a third mound (covered with vegetation?) rises above the straw left of Job's right hand.

Job's wife stands or kneels behind him, her arms bent sharply upward at the elbows, palms out (and slightly up) and fingers spread. Her expression is that of grief and despair. She is gowned, has long hair, and faces forward, with her head twisted to the left and down. She looks down upon Job. Her mouth is slightly open; she may be speaking or crying out in lamentation.

Job's three friends enter in a rush, arms and hands raised, on the left. Eliphaz the Temanite is the figure leading the group; his identity is made clear in Object 11 (plate numbered 9). His hair is fairly long, but not as long as his flowing beard. He is gowned and faces right; both of his bare feet and the agitated hem of his garment are prominent. The fingers of both raised hands (palms up or out) are spread apart. His mouth is open, as though speaking. His visage suggests grief and surprise.

Job's three friends enter in a rush, arms and hands raised, on the left. If the friends enter in the same order as they are introduced in Job 2:11, then the middle figure is Bildad the Shuhite. His hair and beard are curly. He is gowned and faces right; his bare right foot is pictured. The fingers of both raised hands (palms up or out) are spread apart. His head is bent back so that his head faces up; his mouth is open, as though speaking or possibly praying.

Job's three friends enter in a rush, arms and hands raised, on the left. If the friends enter in the same order as they are introduced in Job 2:11, then the last figure on the left is Zophar the Naamathite. We see only his arms, head, and upper body. His hair would appear to be long; only a bit of his beard on his right cheek is pictured. He is gowned and faces right. The fingers of both raised hands (palms up) are spread apart. His head is bent back so that his head faces up.
Walls and/or pillars, perhaps of a (ruined?) building, rise along the right margin of the central design. There are also two steps, lower right. All these structures would appear to be made of stone.
A low (stone?) wall forms the backdrop for Job's right lower arm and hand.
Several ruined structures rise among the hills in the middle distance of the central design. These include walls (of buildings?), broken pillars, and a trilithon. All are probably made of stone.

Some grass, a few spiky plants, and some thorny branches (lower right, with a few leaves) adorn the foreground just above the lower margin of the central design. The reticulated surface of a large bush or hedge, or a mound cover with indeterminate vegetation, appears between the low wall (left of Job's left hand) and the left knee of the right-most friend on the left.
The middle distance is dominated by low hills, with larger mountains on the horizon. Above these are spiky beams of light and a burst of radiance, probably from a rising—or more probably setting—sun.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The lower border design is a landscape with low hills and a clump of trees on the left. In the same lower left corner stands a shepherd (perhaps female) leaning against a leafless tree. She holds a shepherd's crook; a dog sits before here. In the lower right corner are a sheep, a ram, and an elderly shepherd with his crook. He also leans against a leafless tree. Female figures—gowned and bent over as if in grief, melancholy, or despair—adorn the upper corners of the inner framing lines. Cloud outlines surround them and extend through the upper border.

component.illusobjdesc: The lower border design is a landscape with low hills and a clump of trees on the left.
The lower border design is a landscape with low hills and a clump of trees on the left.

A shepherd with long hair, possibly female, stands and leans against a tree in the lower left corner of the border design. One leg is extended backward, as though for support. Her arms are crossed at the wrists; she holds a shepherd's crook in her left hand. She is gowned and faces to the right, but with her head turned toward us and bent down. Her eyes may be closed—or at least turned downward.
A dog sits in the lower right corner of the border design. His head is twisted up to look at the shepherd.

An aged shepherd, with long hair and beard, stands (facing left) and leans against a leafless tree in the lower right corner of the border design. He is apparently holding the shepherd's crook that extends above his head; his left arm may be bent at the elbow. His head is bent down; his eyes may be closed—or at least turned down.
A sheep and a ram, the latter with a looped horn, lie prone just to the left of the shepherd in the lower right corner of the border design. They may be sleeping with eyes closed and are facing left.
A leafless tree rises from the lower left corner of the border design. Its branches extend half-way up the left border.
A leafless tree rises from the lower right corner of the border design. Its branches extend half-way up the right border.
Cloud outlines extend through the upper border design and extend down both side borders. The central cloud bears a text.

A gowned figure, probably female, sits on the top left corner of the inner framing lines. Her bent and crossed legs dangle into the left side border. She faces to the left and is bent over, with her head down and resting in her raised left hand. Her hair is long and her eyes may be closed (or at least turned down). Her posture suggests despair, melancholy, or grief.

A gowned figure, probably female, sits on the top right corner of the inner framing lines. Her bent legs dangle into the right side border. She faces to the right and is bent over, with her head down and resting in her raised left hand. Her right arm, bent at the elbow, rests in her lap. Her hair is long and her eyes may be closed (or at least turned down). Her posture suggests despair, melancholy, or grief.
