desc.related: The very light sketch of the lowered head and back of a figure seen in profile, above and right of center on this sketchbook leaf, may be related to one of Job’s friends, kneeling on the right in Object 10 of the engravings, or to Job’s wife, kneeling at Job’s feet in Object 8 of the engravings.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Job, in his agony and despair, sits on a bed of straw in the middle of the central design. He is nude except for a rough (burlap?) cloth over his lap. He faces forward, with knees drawn up and both feet prominent. His arms are raised vertically, with the palms of his raised hands up and out. His hair is probably long; tears cascade down his cheeks and long beard. His mouth is open; he may be speaking or crying out in pain. The rough texture of his flesh suggests the boils that afflict him. To the left is Job's wife, kneeling and hunched over in grief and despair. Her contracted body, facing right, is gowned; her long hair cascades over her face. On the right, also kneeling and hunched over with faces obscured, are Job's three friends. If our identifications in Object 9 (the plate numbered 7) are correct, then these are (from left to right) Eliphaz (or possibly Zophar), Bildad, and Zophar (or possibly Eliphaz). All are gowned. A few spikes of grass, a thorny branch, and perhaps some stones (lower right) adorn the foreground. An archway, with heavy post and lintel, stands in the middle distance on the right. A low hill, possibly covered with vegetation, extends through the entire middle distance. Behind this whole scene are a range of mountains and a stormy sky filled with dark clouds and possibly smoke.

component.illusobjdesc: Job, in his agony and despair, sits on a bed of straw in the middle of the central design. He is nude except for a rough (burlap?) cloth over his lap. He faces forward, with knees drawn up and both feet prominent. His arms are raised vertically, with the palms of his raised hands up and out. His hair is probably long; tears cascade down his cheeks and long beard. His mouth is open; he may be speaking or crying out in pain. The rough texture of his flesh suggests the boils that afflict him.
Job sits on a bed of straw piled into a mound.
Job's wife kneels to the left of her husband. She is hunched over in a posture expressive of grief and despair. Her contracted body, facing right, is gowned; her long hair cascades over her face.

Job's three friends kneel, facing left, in severely contracted postures expressive of grief or despair. Their faces are hidden, and all three figures wear gowns. Given their identifications we have proposed in Object 9 (the plate numbered 7), the front-most figure is either Eliphaz (although his hair is much longer here than in Object 9) or Zophar. His left arm is bent sharply at the elbow as he reaches forward with his left hand (fingers spread) over his cascading hair.

Job's three friends kneel, facing left, in severely contracted postures expressive of grief or despair. Their faces are hidden, and all three figures wear gowns. Given their identifications we have proposed in Object 9 (the plate numbered 7), the middle figure is probably Bildad (note the curly hair).

Job's three friends kneel, facing left, in severely contracted postures expressive of grief or despair. Their faces are hidden, and all three figures wear gowns. Given their identifications we have proposed in Object 9 (the plate numbered 7), the last figure in the group, closest to Job, is probably Zophar, although he might be Eliphaz. We see only the top of his head, covered with (long?) hair. A pair of clasped hands probably belongs to this last figure in the group.
A bit of spiky vegetation, probably grass and a short thorny vine or branch, appears below Job's wife and just above the lower left margin of the central design.
A few plants and a bit of grass appear below Job's friends and just above the lower right margin of the central design. The rounded forms might be either lobed leaves or stones.
A low hill fills the middle distance behind the figures.
The reticulated surface of the low hill in the middle distance suggests vegetation of some sort.
Dark mountains define the horizon in the central design. The mountain peak on the left seems oddly tilted to the left.
Dark clouds fill the sky in the central design. The most prominent billows upward, and thus these may be clouds of smoke from the continued destruction of Job's world.
An archway, with heavy stone post and lintel, dominates the middle distance behind Job's friends.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Two cloud outlines adorn the upper border design. Raindrops descend from two cloud outlines in the lower side borders. A good deal of vegetation appears in the lower border; from left to right these are a plant or small tree with flowers and fruit, a thorny vine that extends to the right margin, spiky grass, two large mushrooms and two plants (or clusters of small mushrooms?) bearing leaves (?) at the end of short stems, more spiky grass, a thistle, and a plant with spiky leaves bearing flowers and fruit.

component.illusobjdesc: Cloud outlines adorn the upper border design. The text appears to float on the cloud.
A cloud outline, with drops of rain descending from it, appears in the lower left margin.
A cloud outline, with drops of rain descending from it, appears in the lower right margin.
A thorny, snake-like vine extends along the lower border of the lower marginal design.

Several plants appear in the lower left margin. These are, from left to right, a plant or small tree with branches bearing flowers and fruit, spiky grass, a large mushroom, and either a cluster of small mushrooms or a plant with leaves at the end of short stems.

Several plants appear in the lower right margin. These are, from right to left, a plant with spiky leaves and branches bearing flowers and fruit, a thistle, spiky grass, either a cluster of small mushrooms or a plant with leaves at the end of short stems, and a large mushroom.

lg.l: Lo let that night be solitary
& let no joyful voice come therein
Let the Day perish wherein I was Born

nights & none spake a word unto him for they saw that his grief

illustration.illusobjdesc: Eliphaz kneels, lower right, with left arm raised as he tells his vision of God to Job and his wife. Job's two other friends, Bildad and Zophar, kneel near the right margin. Job, again on his bed of straw, looks upward to the vision of God, standing, with a halo and beams of light around him. Eliphaz, in his vision above, is in bed, his hand gesture and hair standing on end indicating his fear of God. The vision in the sky is surrounded by dark cloud bands. Below, in a landscape defined by a dark sky and mountains on the horizon, we also find Job's wife, seated on the far left and with her face turned upward. A few blades of grass and perhaps small plants adorn the foreground just above the lower border of the central design.

component.illusobjdesc: Job sits or reclines on his bed of straw. His knees, drawn up, are covered by a rough (burlap?) cloth; his left foot pokes out from below this garment. His upper body is unclothed. He props up his body with his left arm, bent at the elbow; his right arm is bent across his chest, with the fingers of his right hand spread apart. His body faces forward, but his head is twisted up to look at the vision of God in the sky. His hair and beard are long.
Job reclines on a bed or low mound of straw.

Job's wife sits or kneels in the lower left corner of the central design. She faces forward, but she twists her head upward to look at the vision of God above. She is gowned, with her right arm by her side and her right hand on the ground. Her left arm is bent at the elbow, with her right hand across her breast. Her mouth is slightly open; she may be speaking.

Eliphaz kneels lower right, his left arm and hand (palm up) raised toward his vision of God he is describing to Job. He is gowned and faces left; his beard and hair are long. His right arm extends toward his knees, upon which his right hand rests.

Two of Job's friends kneel or sit near the lower right margin of the central design. Given our identifications of the friends in Object 9 (the plate numbered 7), the friend farthest to the left is Bildad (note the curly hair and beard). He is gowned and faces left, with his head twisted up and to the right. His hands are clasped together under his chin in an attitude of prayer. His mouth may be slightly open.

Two of Job's friends kneel or sit near the lower right margin of the central design. Given our identifications of the friends in Object 9 (the plate numbered 7), the third figure from the front is probably Zophar. He is probably kneeling, like his companion, but we can see only his upturned face. His mouth may be slightly open (in prayer?).

In Eliphaz's vision, pictured in the sky, God stands as an ancient patriarch with long hair and beard. He is gowned and faces right, his right arm apparently bent at the elbow and extended over his chest beneath his garment. He appears to be looking directly at Eliphaz to the right. His head is surrounded by a halo.

In Eliphaz's vision, pictured in the sky, his visionary self appears. He reclines in a bed, his body propped up against a pillow. He faces left and has a long beard. His hair stands on end, indicating fright at the vision of God before him. His left arm is bent at the elbow, with the palm of his left hand (fingers slightly spread) facing toward God. Eliphaz wears a gown (nightgown?), or at least a shirt. His mouth may be open slightly and his eyes are wide open as he beholds his vision of God.
In his vision, Eliphaz lies in bed, a sheet covering his body up to the chest. There would appear to be a pillow behind his head.

Beams of light and radiance extend outward from God, and from his halo, in the vision in the sky. Some shafts extend downward from below God and across the dark cloud separating the vision in the sky from the figures on the earth below.
Eliphaz's vision in the sky is framed by dark cloud bands.
The foreground just above the lower margin of the central design is adorned with some grass and perhaps (below Eliphaz) a small plant.
The horizon, in the lower portion of the central design, is defined by distant mountains.

The sky, between the mountains of the lower portion of the central design and the cloud-framed vision above, is defined by hatching lines that hint at dark clouds. This may be a night (or twilight) scene.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Cloud outlines extend through the upper border design and extend half-way down both margins. The lower border, and the lower half of both side borders, are dominated by the trunks and branches of large, leafless, and probably dead trees. The line surrounding the inscription in the lower border may be another cloud outline. A few lines lower right suggest grass.

component.illusobjdesc: Cloud outlines extend through the upper border design and extend half-way down both margins. A text appears to be written on this cloud.
The line surrounding the inscription in the lower border design may be a cloud outline bearing a text.
The trunks and branches of leafless (and dead?) trees extend up the left margin.
The trunks and branches of leafless (and dead?) trees extend up the right margin.
A few hatching lines, lower right in the border design, hint at blades of grass.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Job kneels on his bed of straw, center left, his mouth slightly open and tears running down his cheeks and long beard. He is nude above the waist; a piece of rough (burlap?) cloth covers his loins and legs. His hands are down by his thighs, palms out. The rough texture of his flesh, particularly visible on his lower arms, suggests the boils that plague him. His eyes appear to be turned slightly upward, as though he is beseeching his God. lg.l: But he knoweth the way that I take
when he hath tried me I shall come forth like gold
Have pity upon me! Have pity upon me! O ye my friends
for the hand of God hath touched me
Though he slay me yet will I trust in him
The Just Upright Man is laughed to scorn
Man that is born of a Woman is of few days & full of trouble
he cometh up like a flower & is cut down. he fleeth also as a shadow
& continueth not, And dost thou open thine eyes upon such a one
& bringest me into judgment with thee

illustration.illusobjdesc: Now at his lowest point, physically and spiritually, Job lies supine on a bed or bier and confronts the devil/god of his false vision. Entwined with a serpent and cloven-footed, that god points up and to the left with his right hand toward the decalogue; with his left he points downward to hell. Lightning and dark clouds fill the distant sky. Below, two devils reach upward toward Job, apparently in an attempt to drag him to the fires of hell below. A third devil with scaly skin holds a chain to bind Job's body and mind.

component.illusobjdesc: Job lies supine on a bed or bier. His legs are together; a rough cloth (burlap?) covers his loins. His body faces upward, but his head is turned toward us as he looks down at the fiery pit below. His open mouth—indeed, his whole visage—expresses terror. He may be speaking crying out in fear.

Job's false vision of god hovers horizontally above the afflicted man. He is aged and gowned, with long, twisted, and spiky hair (rather flame-like) and a long beard. Only his left foot is visible; it is a cloven hoof. His right arm is raised at 45 degrees as he points to the decalogue in the background. His left arm, raised at 135 degrees relative to his body, points downward to hell. He is intertwined with a serpent and his lips are parted slightly; he may be speaking. He looks downward toward his victim.

The middle-distance is filled with low hills, a ruined building, and a large column, or post and lintel, on the far right. Stars shine in the night sky above a distant mountain. The broken fragments of a pot lie on the ground between Elihu's feet; grass and possibly small plants appear on the ground to the right.

desc.objtitle: The Lord Answering Job out of the Whirlwind, Object 15 (Bentley 421.14)

illustration.illusobjdesc: God hovers, arms outstretched, in a whirlwind. Below are Job and his wife (left), both with hands raised in prayer. Job's three friends bow down as though humbled and frightened by God's sublime energies; only Job and his wife gaze upward toward God. Given our identifications of the three friends in Object 9 (the plate numbered 7), these are (from front to back)Eliphaz, Bildad, and Zophar. Grass and perhaps small plants appear in the foreground below the figures; the middle distance is filled with columns and a long lintel, perhaps both parts of a building. The sky appears dark above the distant mountains.

component.illusobjdesc: God appears in a whirlwind. In an early proof state, the whirlwind extends above the upper framing lines of the central design.

God hovers in a whirlwind. He is ancient and gowned, with extremely long beard and hair. He faces forward and to the left, arms outstretched horizontally. He looks slightly down towards Job and his wife. Both hands, with fingers spread and palms down, and his right foot are prominent. He may be blessing Job with his right hand and pointing to the right with the index finger of his left hand.

Job kneels on the left, covered only by the rough cloth covering his lap. He is old and bearded, and has long hair. He faces to the right and up, gazing upon the vision of God in a whirlwind. His arms are bent upward, with his hands clasped together in prayer. His lips are slightly parted; he appears to be surprised by the vision.

Job's wife kneels behind and to the right of her husband. Like him, her arms are bent upward with her hands together in prayer. Her body faces right, with her head turned partly forward and upward; she is probably looking at God above. She is gowned; her hair would appear to be long.

Job's three friends bow down as though humbled and frightened by God in the whirlwind above them. Given our identifications of the three friends in Object 9 (the plate numbered 7), the front-most figure is probably Eliphaz. He is kneeling with his body bent forward in a severely contracted posture. He is gowned and his hair would appear to be long. His arms are bent upward, with the fingers of both prominent hands spread apart. His body faces to the left, with his head down.

Job's three friends bow down as though humbled and frightened by God in the whirlwind above them. Given our identifications of the three friends in Object 9 (the plate numbered 7), the middle figure is probably Bildad. He is probably kneeling, with his body bent forward in a severely contracted posture. He is gowned and his hair is short and curly (his identifying feature in several plates). His body faces to the left, with his head down; we see only his back and the top of his head.

Job's three friends bow down as though humbled and frightened by God in the whirlwind above them. Given our identifications of the three friends in Object 9 (the plate numbered 7), the third figure from the front is probably Zophar. Like his companions, he is probably kneeling, with his body bent forward in a severely contracted posture. His body must be facing to the left, with his head down, but we see only the top and left side of his head.
The foreground below the figures contains grass and perhaps some small plants.
The middle distance on the left contains some pillars and a long lintel, possibly part of a colonnade or building.
The sky is dark above distant mountains on the horizon. A cloud aches upper left and appears again beneath the framing lines on the right, descending below God's left hand.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The whirlwind motif of the central design is repeated in the upper reaches of the border design. Within it are at least five figures, three facing forward and two facing away from the viewer. Those facing forward are old and bearded. In the lower border are two large trees, bent low to the earth—probably by the storm indicated by the rain and hail descending from clouds in the lower right and left corners of the plate's borders.

His left arm is raised vertically, relative to his body; his left hand would seem to be holding the hand or wrist of the figure to the right. His eyes may be closed or at least severely lowered.

His right arm and hand touches the figure to the right.

desc.objtitle: When the Morning Stars Sang Together, Object 16 (Bentley 421.15)

illustration.illusobjdesc: The complex design is divided by cloud bands into three sections. In the top section are stars and four youthful male angels, plus the arms of two more extending from the margins. All are winged and partly nude, with indications of gowns or drapery; their arms overlap at 135 degree angles. In light of the inscription below the central design ("When the morning Stars sang together . . ."), these figures are probably personifications of the stars. The middle section is anchored by the ancient figure of God kneeling in the center of the design. His arms are outstretched horizontally. Beneath his right arm is a youthful male riding one or more of the four horses beneath him. The radiant disc behind his head suggests that he is a sun god, perhaps Apollo. Beneath God's left arm is a winged female holding the reins of two serpents. The crescent moon above her head identifies her as a moon goddess, probably Diana or Hecate. Job and his wife sit or kneel in the lowest section of the design. On the right are Job's three friends. Given our identifications of the friends in object 9 (the plate numbered 7), these are, from right to left, Eliphaz, Bildad, and Zophar. A few plants and tufts of grass grow along the bottom margin of the central design.

component.illusobjdesc: A thin cloud band extends horizontally beneath the feet of the four angels. A thicker band appears behind and on each side of God's extended arms. Two further narrow and vertical bands of clouds are pictured right and left of the two fully-pictured angels on the upper right and left.

A prominent cloud band separates God (center of the design) from the human figures of Job, his wife and three friends, seated below. The clouds descend toward the ground in the right and left margins to form an arch-like form.
The ground just above the bottom margin of the central design shows tufts of grass and perhaps other small plants.
There are 19 stars in the night(?) sky. Six overlap with the winged figures, of which two are simply white areas without engraved outlines.

In the top section are stars and four youthful and winged male angels, plus the arms of two more extending from the margins. All are winged and have their arms raised and overlapping at a 135 degree angle. Their hands are raised, with palms turned upward. Some have fingers spread slightly apart. They face forward, with one foot forward of the other as though walking or striding forward. The back foot appears to be on tiptoe. Their hair is long. They appear to be partly nude, at least from the waist up, with indications of drapery or gowns on each side of their legs. In light of the inscription below the central design ("When the morning Stars sang together . . ."), these figures are probably personifications of the stars. Their open mouths indicate that they are singing.

God—ancient, gowned, and bearded with long flowing hair—anchors the center of the composition. He sits, squats, or kneels on a cloud band, with his right leg pulled up toward his body (as a result, his right knee and foot are prominent). He faces forward, with arms outstretched horizontally and the fingers of both hands spread slightly apart. The palms of his raised hands face downward. A halo surrounds his head. The flowing hem of his garment is prominent.

A youthful and nude male with arms raised horizontally, palms out, appears below God's right arm. He may be pushing against the clouds he touches with both hands. He faces forward and to the left, with his torso bent forward. A halo, or perhaps the disc of the sun with beams of radiance, appears behind his head. He would seem to be riding on the back of one of the horses pictured beneath him. A line extending above and to the right of his left shoulder suggests a wing. His hair is long and curly. Given all these attributes and emblematic associations, this is very probably a sun god, perhaps Apollo.
A youthful and nude male, perhaps Apollo, appears below God's right arm. A halo, or perhaps the disc of the sun with beams of radiance, appears behind his head.
Four horses, in serried rank, appear below the youthful figure below God's right arm. They charge to the left. The front-most steed has its mouth open and its tail is pictured.

A winged and gowned female appears below God's left arm. She faces forward and to the right, with her arms extended horizontally before her. The palms of her raised hands face down. Her hair is fairly short and curly. She holds the reins of two serpents in her hands. The serpents and the crescent moon above her head identify the figure as a moon goddess, perhaps Diana or Hecate (the latter more frequently associated with serpents).
The female figure below God's left arm holds the reins of two serpents.
The female figure below God's left arm holds the reins of two crested serpents. They face to the right, with mouths open and tongues visible.
A crescent moon floats in the night(?) sky just above the head of the female figure below God's left arm.

Job's wife sits or kneels lower left. She is gowned, with long hair, and faces forward with eyes turned upward. Her arms are bent at the elbows with her palms raised vertically. Although there is a gap between her hands, her gesture suggests an attitude of prayer.

Job sits on the ground, the second figure from the left. His rough cloth extends over his lower body; his upper body is undraped. His left knee is drawn up toward his torso, with his left foot visible beneath the cloth. He faces forward, with eyes turned upward. His head is bent back very slightly. Both arms are bent over his body, with his right hand raised vertically as if in prayer, his left hand over his chest and touching his upper right arm. As a result, his lower arms cross each other. He is, as usual, old and bearded with long hair.

Job's three friends sit or kneel lower right. Given our identifications of the friends in Object 9 (the plate numbered 7), these are, from right to left, Eliphaz, Bildad, and Zophar. Eliphaz is old and bearded with long hair. He wears a gown, and would appear to be kneeling. He faces up and to the left, with his eyes raised and his head bent back. His left arm is bent at the elbow, with his left hand raised, palm out, as if in prayer or supplication. The fingers of his left hand are slightly spread. His right hand rests on his (?) right leg just above the knee. The position of the thumb indicates that this could not be the left hand of his companion Bildad, although the position of the knee suggests that the leg might be his. But assuming that the knee and leg do belong to Eliphaz, then his bare right foot is prominent.

Job's three friends sit or kneel lower right. Given our identifications of the friends in Object 9 (the plate numbered 7), these are, from right to left, Eliphaz, Bildad, and Zophar. Bildad (the center figure) has curly hair and a curly beard. He appears to be half- kneeling, with his left leg raised and bent at the knee and his bare left foot prominent. He is gowned and faces forward, to the left, and up, for his head is bent back and eyes raised. His arms are not pictured (see the right arm and hand position of Eliphaz, the front-most figure).

Job's three friends sit or kneel lower right. Given our identifications of the friends in Object 9 (the plate numbered 7), these are, from right to left, Eliphaz, Bildad, and Zophar. The last, the friend furthest to the left, is partly obscured by Bildad; consequently, it is unclear whether Zophar is sitting or kneeling. He is gowned and bearded, as in other plates. Both hands are raised, with palms out and fingers spread. He faces forward, to the left, and up, with head bent back and eyes raised.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The complex border design at the top features stars, an odd cloud-like form stretching horizontally, and winged angels at each top corner of the framing lines for the central design. Both would appear to be holding scrolls. A series of circular designs, bordered by clouds but arranged in a manner that suggests the Tree of Jesse motif, fill the left and right margins. On the left, top to bottom, are images of light, the earth with the waters above and below, and a landscape with mountains and the sea. In the niches of the right margin are, top to bottom, stars and three heavenly spheres, birds and sea creatures (rather serpent-like), and the beasts of the land (ox, horse, lion, ram, and deer or stag). The lower margin is dominated by a serpent-like creature, with his head on the right—perhaps a cousin of the Leviathan in the next plate (Object 17, the plate numbered 15), given the watery environment. Below this creature is a vermicular or serpentine form intertwined with a columnar form (more sea beasts?). Flames rise above the waves lower right and left.

component.illusobjdesc: Ten stars decorate the top right and left margins. A cloud-like form extends horizontally just above the framing line of the central design.

A winged (and possibly gowned) angel hovers(?) at the top left corner of the frame for the central design. Both arms are extended horizontally to the right and rest upon the top frame. A round object, possibly the end of a partly-rolled scroll (see the companion figure on the right), rests under, and may be held by, the angel's right hand. His body faces to the right, but his head is twisted back to the left.

The round object under the right hand of the angel at the top right corner of the central design's frame may be the rolled end of a scroll, as it more clearly is with the companion figure in the top right corner. Alternatively, this may be a sphere or globe, like some of the heavenly bodies pictured elsewhere in the border design.

A winged (and possibly gowned) angel hovers(?) at the top right corner of the frame for the central design. Both arms are probably extended horizontally to the left and rest upon the top frame. A round object, probably the end of a partly-rolled scroll (see the companion figure to the right), appears to the left of the angel's arms. He may be holding this object. His body faces to the left, but his head is twisted back to the right.
The rolled end of a scroll appears to the left of the angel decorating the top right corner of the central design's frame. See the similar object near (perhaps held by) the companion figure top left.
Each side border contains three niches framed by cloud outlines bearing texts. Although not made of vegetation, the pattern suggests the traditional Tree of Jesse motif.
Flames appear in the lower right border design above the head of the sea serpent. A few smaller flames can also be seen near the right outer margin between the cloud frames of the niches.
Flames appear in the lower left border design above the tail of the sea serpent.
The left margin contains three niches framed by clouds. In the top niche we find only beams of radiance to accompany the word "Light." See Genesis 1:3.

The left margin contains three niches framed by clouds. The central niche contains a sphere or globe surrounding the word "Firmament" (or heaven—see Genesis 1:6-8). Above and below the globe are wavy lines probably representing water.
The left margin contains three niches framed by clouds. The bottom niche is a landscape composed of the sea, the shore, and mountains—see Genesis 1:9-10.

The right margin contains three niches framed by clouds. Stars and three globes (two inscribed "Sun" and "Moon") appear in the top niche. The largest, central globe is probably the earth. See Genesis 1:16-17.
The right margin contains three niches framed by clouds. The central niche contains the sea (with creatures).

The right margin contains three niches framed by clouds. Three serpents or fish, facing right, swim in the waters of the sea in the central niche. All have their mouths open and we can see the tongues of the two larger creatures. Birds soar on extended wings in the air above. The three largest face upward with open mouths, as though singing. See Genesis 1:20.

The right margin contains three niches framed by clouds. The bottom niche houses five animals: a cow or ox with horns, a horse (its head is just left of the cow), a lion, a horned sheep or ram (foreground), and the head of a deer or stag with large antlers just above the back of the ox. The sheep lies on the ground; the other beasts are standing. See Genesis 1:24-25.

The right margin contains three niches framed by clouds. The bottom niche houses five animals. Just to the right of the lion are a few lines hinting at vegetation, perhaps small plants—although these lines may simply be the legs of the cow or ox.
The serpent dominating the lower border would appear to be swimming in the sea. Its waves foam dramatically lower right and left.

A rather fishy sea serpent—with scales on its back, a crested head, and a lively tail—dominates the lower margin. This may be a cousin to the Leviathan pictured in Object 17 (the plate numbered 15). The beast faces to the right.
A tubular object, perhaps a creature of some sort, has a worm coiled around it just above the bottom margin of the marginal design.

illustration.illusobjdesc: God appears at the top center of the central design. He reaches down with his left arm, much like the figure on the frontispiece to Europe, and points toward the circle or sphere in which are pictured Behemoth and Leviathan. Several stars and a cloud band, on which God appears to lean, fill the night sky. Winged and gowned angels in attitudes of prayer frame this upper portion of the design. The cloud band descends around both sides of the design and extends below the circle or sphere at the bottom. Job, his wife, and three friends kneel on the ground between God and the beastly sphere and look down toward it. Given our identifications of the friends in object 9 (the plate numbered 7), they are, from right to left, Eliphaz, Bildad, and Zophar. The creatures within the circle or sphere are accompanied by reeds (some with catkins) and a frothy wave of the sea in which Leviathan disports.

component.illusobjdesc: God—old, bearded, and with long hair—anchors the top center of the central design. He faces forward, but we see only his shoulders, arms, and head. His body is obscured by the cloud band on which he leans with his bent right arm and the upper part of his left arm. The fingers of his right hand (which may be holding the cloud) are spread apart. He reaches downward with his left arm, in a gesture very similar to the figure's on the frontispiece to Europe, and points downward with his extended left index finger. No clothes are indicated; his eyes are turned sharply downward. God's head is framed by a circular halo.

A cloud band circumscribes much of the central design. At the top, it extends below, and perhaps supports, God; descends in both the right and left margins; and curves inward in the lower reaches of the design below the circle or sphere.

Six stars fill the night sky right and left of God at the top of the central design. Ten more stars fill the sky below the cloud band below God; thus, these stars are part of the section of the design devoted to Job, his wife, and his friends.
A few lines, right and left on the ground below Job, his wife, and friends, indicate blades of grass.

Two hovering angels—winged, gowned, and with long hair—frame God in the upper reaches of the central design. The angel on the left faces to the right, with his arm bent at the elbow and the lower arm raised in an attitude of worshipful prayer. Although only one hand is pictured, his hands may be together and both may be touching his face. His lower right leg and foot are visible among the drapery trailing from his gown.

Two hovering angels—winged, gowned, and with long hair—frame God in the upper reaches of the central design. The angel on the right faces to the left, with his arm bent at the elbow and the lower arm raised in an attitude of worshipful prayer. Although only one hand is pictured, his hands may be together and both may be touching his face. His lower left leg and foot are visible among the drapery trailing from his gown.

Job's wife sits or kneels in a contracted posture just to the left of her husband. She is gowned and has long hair; her upper body leans forward and she faces to the right. Her arms are crossed over her chest. Her eyes are cast downward, probably to look at the beasts below.

Job—bearded, old, and with long hair—kneels or sits in a contracted posture just below the figure of God. His rough cloth lies over his lap and legs; a cuff at his right wrist hints at a shirt or gown covering his upper body. He faces forward, down, and to the right, with his arms crossed over his chest. He is probably looking down at the beasts to which God points. The fingers of his left hand are spread apart.

Job's three friends kneel or sit just right of God's downward-reaching arm. Given our identifications of the friends in Object 9 (the plate numbered 7), they are, from right to left, Eliphaz, Bildad, and Zophar. All three may be looking, with downcast eyes, at the beasts below. Eliphaz leans forward, facing down and to the left, in a decidedly contracted posture. His left arm is bent sharply at the elbow, with his upper left arm close to his chest. His hair and beard are long; he is probably gowned. His left knee is prominent.

Behemoth is the upper-most of the two biblical beasts pictured within a circle or globe. He stands, or possibly strides, facing left, with his head turned partly forward. Behemoth's muscles and tendons are visible, as though the creature lacked skin. His large ear is anthropomorphic; large teeth or tusks extend from his partly-open mouth. The hair(?) on his back appears to be twisted or knotted into a lattice-like pattern. His tongue is discernable within his slightly-opened mouth.

Leviathan is the lower of the two biblical beasts pictured within a circle or globe. He is a giant sea-serpent with large teeth filling his partly-open mouth. His crested head faces up, with a loop of his scaly body on the left.
Reeds with catkins frame Behemoth on the right and left. The vertical lines below Behemoth's belly suggest more reeds in the background.
Behemoth stands on marshy or sandy ground, perhaps on the shore of the sea in which Leviathan wreathes.

illustration.illusobjdesc: God sits, apparently enthroned on a plinth or at the top of steps, at the top center of the central design. He holds an open book on his lap; he raises his right hand, palm out, in a sign of blessing. A giant halo, two winged putti, and four children surround him, with beams of light and cloud bands further from him right and left. Two large angels hover nearby, right and left. A tongue of flame contains a vision of Satan falling headlong into bolts of lightning and the fires of hell below. The two figures with him have been variously identified as his fellow-devils and as the fallen selves of Job (right) and his wife (left). On the ground lower left, Job and his wife sit or kneel, beholding the vision in the flame. The landscape in which they appear includes some vegetation (perhaps grass) and the suggestion of a background hill and, just to the right of Job's wife, a cliff or the side of a cave from which issue the fires of hell. Job's three friends kneel, aghast at the vision, lower right. Given our identifications of the friends in Object 9 (the plate numbered 7), these are Zophar (left-most in the group, seen from behind), Bildad (head only, upper right), and Eliphaz (nearest the lower right corner of the design).

component.illusobjdesc: God sits, apparently enthroned on a plinth, at the top center of the central design. He holds an open book on his lap; he raises his right hand, palm out, in a sign of blessing. He is old, with long beard and hair, and wears a flowing gown. The fingers of both hands are slightly spread apart. He faces forward, but leans and looks to the left. The unengraved, egg-shaped area behind God suggests a giant halo. His knees are prominent.
God holds an open book on his lap.

God sits, apparently enthroned, on a stone(?) plinth or at the top of two steps. The halo-like white area behind him emits radiant beams of light. Columns of clouds frame this upper composition and extend two-thirds of the way down the central design.

A winged putto or angel hovers to the left of God's head. We see him from the side, with his right arm bent upward and his face lowered into his right hand. The gesture suggests sorrow or grief. He would appear to be nude, with legs together and slightly bent. His hair is short.

A winged putto or angel hovers to the right of God's head. He faces forward and to the left, with his arms bent upward and his face lowered into his hands. The gesture suggests sorrow or grief. He would appear to be nude, with legs together and slightly bent. His hair is short.
A few short, radiant beams of light appear above the heads of the two putti, right and left of God's head.

A young (nude?) boy, perhaps a putto although no wings are pictured, hovers just right of God's left elbow. We see only his head, the left side of his body, and his bent left arm. He faces forward; his hair is short and curly. His lips may be slightly parted. Some lines of radiance above his head suggest a halo.
A radiant circle of beams of light suggests a halo above the head of the child just to the right of God's left elbow.

Three young boys, perhaps putti although no wings are pictured, hover just left of God's right arm. All three have short, curly hair. We see only the head of the uppermost child, who faces forward. His lips may be slightly parted. Lines of radiance above his head suggest a halo.

Three young boys, perhaps putti although no wings are pictured, hover just left of God's right arm. All three have short, curly hair. We see only the head of the child second from the top; he faces forward. His lips may be slightly parted. Lines of radiance left of his head suggest a halo.

Three young boys, perhaps putti although no wings are pictured, hover just left of God's right arm. All three have short, curly hair. The lowest child in this group faces partly to the left with his head twisted forward; we see only his head, upper body, arms, and hands. His arms are bent upward, with his hands raised, palms up and out and fingers spread. A few lines on his left shoulder hint at a gown.
Radiant beams of light suggest halos around the group of three boys (putti?) left of God's right arm.

A large winged and gowned angel hovers on the left side of the central design. His body faces to the right, with his head turned toward us. His hair is long; he may be smiling. His right arm is bent upward, with the fingers of his right hand slightly spread. The gesture suggests prayer, even though the other hand is not visible. His bare right foot is visible among the drapery of his gown. A white area, with short lines of radiance, suggests a halo around his head.
Radiant but short beams of light define the outer rim of the halo surrounding the head of the large angel on the left side of the central design.
Radiant but short beams of light define the outer rim of the halo surrounding the head of the large angel on the right side of the central design.

A large winged and gowned angel hovers on the right side of the central design. His body faces away from the viewer, with his head turned to the left and slightly down. His hair is long and his legs are together. His right leg is bent at the knee. His head is turned to the left and slightly down. A white area, with short lines of radiance, suggests a halo around his head.
A large, rounded tongue of flame appears below God; within it is a vision of Satan and two other figures (possibly Job and his wife).

Bolts of lightning appear below and on the left side of the large tongue of flame below God. Below these are three more flames (of hell?) that issue upward between cliffs—or possibly the sides of a cave extending down to hell.

A vision of Satan appears as the central figure in the large tongue of flame below God. The two figures with him have been variously identified as his fellow devils and as the fallen forms of Job (right) and his wife (left). All three are falling upside down into the abyss. The figure on the left has her(?) head down, with her arms bent at the elbows and her hands clutching her head. She is seen from behind; her hair is long. Her legs are bent sharply at the knees and pulled up behind her torso; both feet are prominent. She is probably gowned, although there is little in the way of clear evidence of clothing other than the appearance of her buttocks (less individually defined than if unclothed).

A vision of Satan appears as the central figure in the large tongue of flame below God. The two figures with him have been variously identified as his fellow devils and as the fallen forms of Job (right) and his wife (left). All three are falling upside down into the abyss. Satan is seen from the front, with his arms bent behind his head. His mouth is open, perhaps in an expression of pain. His genital region is obscured, perhaps by scales. His left leg is extended; the left foot is prominent. His right leg is bent at the knee. His nude body is slightly twisted.

A vision of Satan appears as the central figure in the large tongue of flame below God. The two figures with him have been variously identified as his fellow devils and as the fallen forms of Job (right) and his wife (left). All three are falling upside down into the abyss. The figure on the right has his head down, with at least his right arm bent over his head. Both arms may be wrapped around his head. He is seen from behind; his hair is long. His legs are bent at the knees and pulled up toward his torso; both feet are prominent. A few lines suggest that his twisted body is gowned.
The sky in the lower half of the central design is very dark; this may be a night scene.
Job and his wife sit on a plot of ground that descends sharply, like the edge of a cliff, just right of the two figures. There appears to be two mounds or low hills behind them.
Some vegetation, perhaps grasses and small plants, grow around and behind Job and his wife in the lower left corner of the central design.
Job's three friends appear to be sitting on a plot of ground in the lower right corner of the central design. The ground falls off sharply on the left, like a cliff.
A few lines hint at grass just below the lower leg of the left-most figure among the huddled group of Job's friends in the lower right corner of the central design.

Job sits or kneels lower left. He is old, with long hair and a beard. He faces forward and to the right, with his head turned upward to view the vision in the large, central flame. He is partly nude, with his rough cloth draped over his loins and legs. His arms are at his side, with his hands down, palms facing down and fingers spread. This gesture suggests surprise. His lips may be slightly parted.

Job's wife sits or kneels, lower left just right of her husband. She now looks old and care-worn. She is gowned, with long hair and her lips slightly parted. Her arms are crossed over her chest, with the fingers of both hands slightly spread. She faces forward, with her head bent back to view the vision in the large, central flame.

Job's three friends huddle, in twisted postures, in the lower right corner of the central design. Given our identification of the friends in Object 9 (the plate numbered 7), they are Zophar (left), Eliphaz (lower right), and Bildad (just above Eliphaz). Zophar is gowned; his hair is long and his left foot is prominent. He may be kneeling, although his body appears to hover slightly off the ground. We see him from behind, with his body twisted to the right and his head twisted to the left. He appears to be looking up at the vision in the large, central flame. His mouth is slightly open; he appears to be amazed or frightened by the vision.

Job's three friends huddle, in twisted postures, in the lower right corner of the central design. Given our identification of the friends in Object 9 (the plate numbered 7), they are Zophar (left), Eliphaz (lower right), and Bildad (just above Eliphaz). Eliphaz is old, bearded, and gowned; his hair is long. He sits or kneels, with his body facing forward and to the right and his head twisted back to the left, and slightly up, to view the vision in the large, central flame. His right arm is bent over his chest, with his right hand (fingers slightly spread) reaching upward toward (or perhaps just touching) his face. The position of his left arm is unclear; it may be hidden beneath his flowing beard.

Job's three friends huddle, in twisted postures, in the lower right corner of the central design. We see only the head (and perhaps a bit of the left side of the torso) of Bildad; he is bearded and his hair is curly. His head is turned upward to view the vision in the large, central flame. His mouth is open, as if he is amazed or frightened by what he sees.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Job stands, with his back to us, before a stone altar, above which rises a triangular or heart-shaped flame. component.illusobjdesc: Job stands, with his back to us, before a stone altar, above which rises a heart-shaped flame. His cruciform posture, with arms extended a little above the horizontal, suggests a self-sacrifice Job is giving to his God and perhaps a type of spiritual ecstasy. He is gowned and bearded, with long hair. The fingers of his extended hands (palms facing up and out) are spread apart. His right leg is slightly bent and extended a bit behind him, with his right foot balanced on tiptoe. His head is turned to the left and tilted upward. His right foot and the flowing hem of his garment are prominent.

Job's wife kneels in prayer just left of her husband. She is gowned and has exceptionally long hair. She faces away and to the right. Her arms are bent upward with her right hand near her face. Her left hand is not pictured, but her posture and gestures suggest that her hands are together in prayer.

Job's three friends kneel lower right. Like Job's wife, they may be praying. Their postures are somewhat contracted as they bend forward. We see them from behind, the soles of their feet visible beneath their gowns. Given our identifications of the friends in object 9 (the plate numbered 7), they are Bildad (the central figure) and Eliphaz and Zophar right and left of Bildad. The representations of Eliphaz and Zophar are in this plate insufficient to discriminate between them. Bildad's hair is curly.

Two steps or a double plinth extend the length of the lower border, with smaller steps or plinths on the left and right from which sprout grain stems, some with tassels. There may be an additional step lower right under the scroll.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Job and his wife sit on the right. His left arm crosses his chest as he holds his upper right arm with his left hand. His left hand is on his knee. His wife crosses her arms over her breasts. Grass covers the ground, with a large leaf in the lower right corner of the central design. A fig tree, bearing fruit, rises to the right of Job; behind Job and his wife are broken stones, perhaps columns or part of a wall. Four standing figures on the left are bringing charitable gifts to the now-humbled couple. These figures are, from left to right, a young woman holding a cloth or net-like purse(?); another young woman, partly obscured by her companion; a tall, bearded man holding a purse or covered vessel of some sort; and a woman with a scarf over her head who holds, in her extended left hand, a star-shaped object, perhaps jewelry. Grain stems with tassels and a distant mountain rise between the two groups of figures.

component.illusobjdesc: Job sits on the right, his head humbly bowed. He is bearded and gowned, with his bare left foot extended beyond the flowing hem of his garment. His hair is long. His left arm is bent at the elbow and extended across his chest, with his left hand resting on, or perhaps holding, his upper right arm. His right arm is extended along his upper right leg, with his right hand resting on his right knee. He faces to the left.

Job's wife sits just to the left of her husband. Her head is humbly bowed, with her eyes lowered and at least partly closed. She is gowned, with long hair, and faces to the left and down. Her arms are crossed over her breast.

The left-most youthful female standing in the group of four figures approaching Job and his wife has curly (and slightly flame- like) hair, blown back as though by a wind. She is gowned and faces to the right. Her arms are bent over her torso, with one hand on her breast. She holds a cloth or net purse(?) in the spread fingers of her left hand. A loop of the purse coils around her right wrist.
The left-most female standing in the group of four figures holds a cloth or net purse(?) in her left hand. A loop of the purse coils around her right wrist.

The young female standing second from the left (in the group of four figures approaching Job and his wife) is partly obscured by her companion to the left. She is gowned and her hair is long, with a curl of hair (or very small bun?) at the top of her head. She faces forward and to the right.

The man standing second from the right (in the group of four figures approaching Job and his wife) holds a triangular container(?) in both hands. His right arm is bent at the elbow. He has a beard, curly hair, a gown, and sandals on his prominent feet. He faces forward and to the right, with his right leg dawn a little behind his left. He is probably walking to the right. His posture suggests that he is about to give something from the container to Job and his wife.

The man in the group of four figures approaching Job and his wife holds a triangular object, probably a container of some sort. This object has sometimes been described as a purse, but it clearly has a small finial at its top. This motif suggests that it is a covered jar, vase, or bowl rather than a purse.

The right-most figure (in the group of four standing figures approaching Job and his wife) is a young woman who holds, in her extended left hand (palm out), a star-shaped object (probably a piece of jewelry). She is probably about to give this to Job's wife. She wears a scarf over her long hair. She faces forward and to the right. The single foot extending from the hem of her gown suggests that she may be walking.

The right-most figure (in the group of four standing figures approaching Job and his wife) is a young woman who holds, in her extended left hand, a star-shaped object. This is probably a piece of jewelry, perhaps a pendant of some sort (note the ring at the top), possibly even a large earring.

Job and his wife may be sitting on a grassy mound, one that extends just right of Job's left hip. However, just above and to the left of his wife's right knee is a stepped object, possibly made of stone, that suggests a seat or bench.
The mound right of Job's left hip is partly covered with grass. Below is at least one large leaf, perhaps a fig leaf fallen from the tree above.
A large fig tree grows right of Job and spreads is leafy and fruit-bearing limbs along the top of the central design.
Grass covers the ground just above the lower margin of the central design.
Grain stems with tassels stand between the two groups of figures.
A distant mountain appears below the extended left arm of the right-most woman in the group of four figures on the left.
Horizontal hatching lines in the sky hint at clouds.
A ruined wall (or perhaps a broken pillar on the left with a wall extending from it on the right) backs Job and his wife.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Large palms, bearing dates, grow in the lower right and left corners of the border design. Their fronds extend up both side borders and additional fronds spread out in the top border, right and left. Cloud outlines fill the top border and frame two hovering, descending figures. Two objects of an indeterminate nature (coins? petals?) appear above the left hand of the figure on the left; the figure on the right holds a vine with leaves in her right hand, with more indeterminate small objects (coins? petals?) floating away from her left hand. Two groups of five figures each hover among the fronds in the upper side margins. Two gowned (or partly gowned) females fill the lower border design; each appears to be floating on scroll-like clouds or drapery. They display flowers and various objects, probably vegetation, in their hands and around their bodies. Large rose-like blooms decorate the base of the palm lower left; lilies fulfill the same role lower right. A few lines suggest grass below the trunks of the two palms.

component.illusobjdesc: A large palm, bearing two bunches of dates, grows up the left margin. Other palm fronds spring from the top left corner of the inner framing lines.
A large palm, bearing two bunches of dates, grows up the right margin. Other palm fronds spring from the top right corner of the inner framing lines.
Cloud bands bearing texts arch through the upper border design, right and left.

A gowned female hovers or soars in a downward arc. Her hair is long, with her body facing forward and to the left and her head twisted back to the right. Her legs are together. Her arms are raised horizontally, relative to her body, and her hands are raised, palms up. Round objects (coins? petals?) appear above her left hand; she may be throwing these into the air.
Round objects (coins? petals?) appear above the upraised left hand of the soaring figure.

A gowned female hovers or soars in a downward arc. Her hair is long, with her body facing away from the viewer and her head twisted back to the left. Her legs are together. Her right arm is raised vertically, relative to her body; her left arm is raised at a little less than 45 degrees. Her hands are raised, palms up. Round objects (coins? petals?) appear above her left hand; she may be throwing these into the air. She holds a small branch or vine (with a few leaves or blossoms) in her right hand.
Round objects, possibly coins or petals, appear above the extended left hand of the soaring figure.
Round objects, possibly coins or petals, appear above the extended left hand of the soaring figure. She holds in her right hand a small vine or branch bearing leaves or blossoms.

Five figures, all probably female, hover above and below the top left corner of the inner framing lines. The lowest figure is gowned and has long hair. She faces forward, with her head turned to the right. Her left arm is bent upward, with her raised left hand (palm out to the left) over her chest.

Five figures, all probably female, hover above and below the top left corner of the inner framing lines. We see only the head and torso of the second figure from the bottom. She is gowned and has long hair. She faces forward, with her head turned to the right.

Five figures, all probably female, hover above and below the top left corner of the inner framing lines. We see only the head and right shoulder of the figure third from the bottom. She faces forward, with her head bent back slightly and turned to the left.

Five figures, all probably female, hover above and below the top left corner of the inner framing lines. We see only the head, upper body, and upper arms (extended horizontally) of the figure second from the top. Her arms may be resting on the inner framing line. She has long hair and may be nude. She faces forward, with her head turned to the left.

Five figures, all probably female, hover above and below the top left corner of the inner framing lines. We see only the head and a bit of the upper body of the top-most figure. She has long hair and faces forward and to the right. A line at her neck suggests that she is gowned.

Five figures, all probably female, hover above and below the top right corner of the inner framing lines. The lowest figure is gowned and has long hair. She faces forward, with her head turned to the left. Her right arm is bent upward, with her raised left hand (palm out to the right) over her chest.

Five figures, all probably female, hover above and below the top right corner of the inner framing lines. We see only the head and part of the upper body of the figure second from the bottom. She may be nude. She faces forward, with her head turned to the left and down.

Five figures, all probably female, hover above and below the top right corner of the inner framing lines. We see only the head of the figure third from the bottom. She faces forward and has long hair.

Five figures, all probably female, hover above and below the top right corner of the inner framing lines. We see only the head, upper body, and arms of the figure second from the top. She may be nude, with her right upper arm extended horizontally along, and perhaps resting upon, the inner framing line. Her left arm is bent upward. She has long hair. She faces forward, with her head tilted to the left.

Five figures, all probably female, hover above and below the top right corner of the inner framing lines. We see only the head and left shoulder of the top-most figure. Her body faces forward, with her head bent back a bit. Her long hair streams out to the right, as though blown by a wind.

In addition to the large palm trunk, the lower left corner of the border design features several vegetative motifs: a few lines representing grass, some spiky leaves behind the palm trunk (possibly a frond fallen from the palm), one or two closed buds, and some large flowers (possibly roses) with a vine or branch between them.

In addition to the large palm trunk, the lower right corner of the border design features several vegetative motifs: a few lines representing grass, some spiky leaves behind the palm trunk (possibly a frond fallen from the palm), and lilies bending down to the ground.

A gowned figure, very probably female, hovers in the lower border design. She appears to be reclining on a scroll-like bed of drapery. We see her from behind, with her head turned upward and to the left. Her hair is long. Her legs are together, with the left slightly bent at the knee. Her left arm is extended along her body; her right arm is bent upward, with her right hand raised, palm up. She may be holding a small vine.
The floating figure appears to be reclining on a bed of scroll-like cloth. Beneath this bed on the left is a cloud outline.

The floating figure may be holding a small vine in her right hand. Below is a branch bearing several leaves or blossoms and, at its top end, a large flower (possibly a rose). The odd shapes above the figures extended left arm may also be vegetative.

A gowned (but perhaps partly nude) female hovers in the lower border design. She appears to be reclining on a scroll-like bed of drapery. She faces forward, with her head turned slightly to the right, and has long hair. Her arms are raised horizontally, with the palms of her hands turned upward. She may be holding (or tossing into the air) small plants or flowers in each hand. Her legs are together, with the left slightly bent at the knee.
The floating figure appears to be reclining on a bed of scroll-like cloth. Beneath this bed is a cloud outline extending to the right.
The floating figure may be holding (or tossing into the air) small branches or vines with flowers in her hands. The odd shapes just below her breasts may also be vegetative (blossoms of some sort?).

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the only indoor scene in the Job series, the aged, bearded, and long-haired patriarch sits with three daughters (two at his side, one kneeling before him). His arms are raised horizontally to point out the pictures on the room's walls. A rectangular wall picture appears above Job's head, with circular pictures behind his hands right and left. All three would appear to represent scenes in Job's own life. Like Blake, Job is telling his story visually. The upper group of pictures shows, from left to right, a group of figures fleeing from bearded attackers with poles or spears, with a (Satanic?) figure hovering above the group; God appearing to Job, his wife and friends, in a whirlwind; and a Satanic figure raining lightning and flames on a plowman. The decorative motifs include a band of serpents beneath the pictures, vegetative motifs on the plinth or wall behind Job, and geometrical shapes on the floor. The back walls, lower right and left, bear two further pictures, each showing a huddled figure (Job's wife in despair?). Above these panels are bearded figures with lightning bolts descending from their outstretched hands.

component.illusobjdesc: Job and his three daughters sit within a room, the three back walls of which contain representational pictures and decorative motifs. The (stone or marble?) floor is elaborately decorated with geometrical designs suggestive of diagrams.

Job—aged, beard, gowned, and with long hair—sits in the center of the design. Three members of his family—all daughters—sit or kneel around him. He faces forward with his arms raised horizontally. His extended hands, fingers slightly spread, point to the paintings on the walls. The palms of his raised hands face down. His legs are spread apart, with his bare right foot partly exposed beneath the flowing hem of his garment. His knees are also prominent.

One of Job's daughters sits just to the left of her father. She is gowned, with legs together and knees prominent (as is the ruffled hem of her garment). Her arms are bent upward and her hands crossed over her breasts. She faces forward, with her head turned a bit to the right. Her hair is long and a little curly.

One of Job's daughters sits just to the right of her father. She is gowned, with legs together and knees prominent (as is the ruffled hem of her garment). Both arms are bent upward, with her left hand (fingers slightly spread) touching, and resting on, her father's left upper leg and her right hand on her breast. She faces forward, with her head turned a bit to the left. Her hair is long and a little curly.

One of Job's daughters kneels in front of her father. We see her from behind, but her head is twisted to the left and down. Her hair is long and curly, with a bun at the back of her head covered by a (cloth?) net. Her arms are down at her side, with her fingers spread just above the floor. The flowing hem of her garment is prominent.

The wall picture on the left includes two running figures; they are fleeing in fear from their attackers on the right. The front- most runner flees to the left, with right arm bent upward and head twisted back to the right. His mouth is open; he may be screaming in fear. Above his head is the head only of another figure; two more such heads, upturned, and upper bodies appear right of his shoulder. Another (running?) figure has his left arm raised horizontally with his extended left hand palm out. The scene suggests the destruction of Job's family.
A figure hovers, arms raised horizontally, above the other figures in the circular picture on the left. His hair is long. He may be Satan, or at least a type of destroying devil.

A (male?) figure lies on the ground at the bottom of the circular picture on the left. His head is twisted up and to the right. His mouth is open; his expression probably indicates fear and pain, given the spear thrust into his stomach.

Two bearded figures with long hair chase and attack fleeing figures in the circular wall picture on the left. Both stride to the left and hold poles or spears. The front-most attacker has his right arm bent upward and his left arm raised vertically. The arm position of his companion is probably similar. A few lines behind them suggest drapery or a gown. The head and upper body of another figure appears far right in this violent picture.
The two bearded figures in the wall picture on the left attack their victims with long poles or spears.

God, with long beard and hair and arms raised horizontally, hovers, facing forward, in a whirlwind in the wall picture above Job's head. His left hand is palm down, his right palm up. The scene is basically the same as the one pictured in Object 15 (plate numbered 13).
God appears in a whirlwind in the wall picture above the central figure of Job.

Job and his wife sit or kneel submissively on the left side of the wall picture above the central figure of Job. She bends forward in a contracted posture, with her arms and hands crossed over her breast. Her hair is long and she is probably gowned. She faces to the right with her head down.

Job and his wife sit or kneel submissively on the left side of the wall picture above the central figure of Job. He bends forward in a contracted posture with his arms bent upward and his hands covering his face. His hair is long; he faces to the right.

Job's three friends kneel, with heads bowed, on the right side of the wall picture above the central figure of Job. They all face to the left in contracted postures with heads down. Given our identification of the friends in Object 9 (the plate numbered 7), these are, from front to back, Eliphaz, Bildad, and Zophar. Eliphaz has his hand raised to his face, perhaps in prayer. He is bearded and gowned and has long hair.

Job's three friends kneel, with heads bowed, on the right side of the wall picture above the central figure of Job. They all face to the left in contracted postures with heads down. Given our identification of the friends in Object 9 (the plate numbered 7), these are, from front to back, Eliphaz, Bildad, and Zophar. We see only the top of Bildad's head and his curly hair.

Job's three friends kneel, with heads bowed, on the right side of the wall picture above the central figure of Job. They all face to the left in contracted postures with heads down. Given our identification of the friends in Object 9 (the plate numbered 7), these are, from front to back, Eliphaz, Bildad, and Zophar. We see only the top of Zophar's head.

In the wall painting right of Job, a man falls backwards, his right hand still grasping the handle of a plow. His head and body are dramatically bent backward, facing up and to the right, with his legs spread apart and his right foot on tiptoe. His right arm is bent sharply at the elbow. He may be wearing tights (nude plowing is rare).
The handles of a plow are held by the man in the foreground of the circular wall picture on the right.
Two buildings, perhaps houses or barns with steeply- pitched roofs, appear behind and to the right of the foreground figure in the circular wall picture on the right.

A male with arms raised vertically hovers at the top of the circular wall picture on the right. He may be Satan, or at least a type of destroying devil. His body faces to the left, but his head faces forward; he has long, flame-like hair. His legs are spread apart; he is probably nude. His hands are raised, palms down; a lightning bolt descends from his left hand and flames cascade from his right.
Flames issue from the right hand, and a lightning bolt from the left hand, of the hovering figure in the circular wall picture on the right.
A bearded head with long hair hovers, facing forward, in the lower wall picture on the left. He may be a devil figure of some sort. Lightning bolts appear to issue from this head.
An arch separates the hovering figure from the contracted figure in the lower wall picture on the left.

A dramatically contracted figure sits or squats below the arch in the lower wall picture on the left. She(?) faces left and down, with her knees drawn up and her head bent on or even below them. She is gowned and has long hair; she may be Job's wife in her despair.

A bearded head with long hair hovers, facing forward, in the lower wall picture on the right. He may be a devil figure of some sort. His left arm is raised horizontally, with a lightning bolt descending from his raised left hand, palm down. His right arm is not pictured, but another lightning bolt appears to issue from the right side of his head.
An arch separates the hovering figure from the contracted figure in the lower wall picture on the right.

A dramatically contracted figure sits or squats below the arch in the lower wall picture on the right. She(?) faces right and down, with her knees drawn up and her head bent on or even below them. She is gowned and has long hair; she may be Job's wife in her despair.

A serpentine vine with spiky leaves—or perhaps an actual serpent—wends its way through a narrow, horizontal wall panel just below the circular wall picture on the left. A sprig of vegetation, including leaves, decorates the top left corner of the rectangular object behind Job.

Two serpentine vines with spiky leaves—or perhaps two actual serpents, one crested—wend their way through a narrow, horizontal wall panel just below the circular wall picture on the right. A short, curled vine bearing a leaf or blossom (possibly a lily) decorates the triangular niche just below and to the right of the circular wall picture. A sprig of leaves appears in the top right corner of the rectangular object behind Job.

A rectangular (stone?) object projects to the left of the lower right leg of Job's daughter seated to the left of him. This may be a corner of the plinth or seat on which all three figures are placed.

A rectangular (stone?) object projects to the right just left of the lower left leg of Job's daughter seated to the right of him. This may be a corner of the plinth or seat on which all three figures are placed.

A rectangular (stone or marble?) object projects from the back wall behind Job. This may be part of the seat or plinth on which Job and two of his daughters are place, but it could also be an altar or even an elevated tomb.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Branches with grape leaves and vine-like tendrils, some with loops, decorate the lower corners of the border design, climb up the side borders, and arch through the top left and right sides of the top border design. Two groups of two angels decorate the top corners of the inner framing lines. In each group, one (a female?) lies on the horizontal framing line; the other (a male?) hovers vertically in the side margin. The lower left marginal design includes a lyre, some grass, and a bunch of grapes; the right lower margin offers a mandolin, some grass, and a bunch of grapes.

component.illusobjdesc: Branches with grape leaves and vine-like tendrils, some with loops, decorate the lower corners of the border design, climb up the side borders, and arch through the top left and right sides of the top border design.

Two winged angels adorn the top left corner of the inner framing lines. One, probably a female, reclines on the horizontal border line. She faces forward and to the left, looking at her companion; her left arm is bent upward and would seem to touch her companion. Her legs may be crossed at the ankles. Her hair is long. It is unclear whether she is nude or gowned.

Two winged angels adorn the top left corner of the inner framing lines. One, probably a male, hovers vertically in the side margin. It is unclear whether he is nude or gowned. He faces away and to the right, with his right arm raised just below the horizontal and his left hand probably touching his companion. His legs are together and his hair is short.

Two winged angels adorn the top right corner of the inner framing lines. One, probably a female, reclines on the horizontal border line. She faces forward and to the right, looking at her companion as she props herself up with her bent left arm. It is unclear whether she is nude or gowned.

Two winged angels adorn the top right corner of the inner framing lines. One, probably a male, hovers vertically in the side margin. It is unclear whether he is nude or gowned. He faces forward and to the left, with his left arm at his side. His legs are together and his hair is short.
Some spiky grass and a cluster of grapes decorate the lower left corner of the marginal design.
A lyre rests in the lower left corner of the marginal design.
A bit of spiky grass and a large bunch of grapes decorate the lower right corner of the marginal design.
A mandolin rests in the lower right corner of the marginal design.
