desc.objtitle: Job and His Family Restored to Prosperity, Object 23 (Bentley 421.22)
desc.related: This sketch may be related, albeit distantly, to the foliage on the large central tree in Objects 3 and 23 of the engravings.

These sketches may be related to the dog with its head resting on the ground in the center foreground of Object 23 of the engravings or to the dog with its head resting on a sheep in the center foreground of Object 3 of the engravings.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The final design mirrors the first (Object 3, the plate numbered 1), but with significant differences. Job's family, restored and reunited, stand and sing or play musical instruments. From left to right they are a youthful male playing double pipes; two of his brothers playing horns; another young son playing a curled horn; a youthful daughter holding an open pamphlet (a musical score?) and possibly singing; Job's wife, playing a mandolin; a young daughter holding a scroll (possibly another musical score) and perhaps singing; Job, playing a large rectangular harp; a young female playing a lyre; a son playing a curled horn and another playing a large harp; and a final youthful male holding a pipe, his mouth open perhaps in song. The instruments hung in the tree in the first scene of the drama are now used to praise God. The great (oak?) tree from the opening scene again anchors the middle of the design; a sun appears over a distant mountain range on the right, and a crescent moon and two stars (or planets) fill the sky on the left. Seven sheep, including one ram, and a dog lie on grass in the foreground. A flock of sheep appear behind the legs of the figures.

component.illusobjdesc: Job's family, restored and reunited, stand and sing or play musical instruments. The patriarch stands, playing a large triangular harp, on the right side of the central tree. He is gowned and bearded; his hair is long. He faces forward, with his left arm raised at 135 degrees and his left hand possibly pointing to the heavens. His right arm is bent across his body, with the fingers of his right hand (slightly spread) placed on the strings of the harp. His bare right foot extends beyond the hem of his gown.

The figure furthest to the left is a young male, one of Job's sons. He is gowned and standing, facing forward and to the right, with his left leg drawn slightly behind his right. His left foot is on tiptoe. His hair is curly. His arms are bent at the elbow and he holds two pipes on which he plays with spread fingers.

The second figure from the left is a youthful male, one of Job's sons, playing a horn. What little we see of his hair suggests that it is curly. He is gowned and standing, with his left arm raised at 135 degrees to hold his horn in his left hand. His head is bent back slightly, with his body facing to the right and his head facing a little up. His bare right foot is prominent.

The third figure from the left is a gowned and youthful male, one of Job's sons, playing a horn. He is standing, with his left leg slightly bent and his left foot behind his right and poised on tiptoe. His head is bent back slightly, with his body facing forward and to the right and his head facing up. His left arm is raised at 135 degrees to hold the large horn.

The fourth figure from the left is a youthful male, one of Job's sons, playing a horn with loops that suggest a spiral. He wears tights, or perhaps a short gown. He is standing, with his right leg slightly bent and his right foot behind his left and poised on tiptoe. He faces forward and to the right, with his head and eyes inclined downward. His right arm is bent upward to hold his horn.

The fifth figure from the left is a young female, one of Job's daughters. She is gowned, with her hair drawn into a bun on the top of her head. She is standing, facing forward and to the left. She holds, in her lowered right hand (and presumably her unpictured right hand) an open pamphlet or slender book—probably a musical score. Although her mouth is not open, she may be singing. Her left foot extends from under the hem of her garment.

Job's wife stands on the left side of the central tree, the sixth figure from the left. She faces forward, holding and playing (with fingers spread) a mandolin. She is gowned, with her left foot extending from under the hem of her garment. Her bent right hand is lowered onto the strings of the instrument. Her hair is long and her lips are slightly parted; she may be singing.

A young female stands, facing forward but with her head turned a bit to the left, in front of the central tree and between Job and his wife. She is one of Job's daughters. She is gowned and has long, curly hair. Both feet emerge just beyond the ruffled hem of her garment. Her arms are lowered at her sides and she holds in her hands a scroll or manuscript, perhaps of music. Although her mouth is not open, she may be singing.

The figure furthest to the right in the family group is a young male, one of Job's sons, with long hair. He wears tights and stands with his right knee slightly bent and his right foot drawn back and on tiptoe. He faces to the left, with head bent back and eyes raised, and holds a pipe with both hands. His mouth is slightly open; he may be playing the pipe (although not at this moment) or singing. His left arm is down at his side; his right arm is bent upward to hold the pipe.

The second figure from the right is a young male, one of Job's sons, who stands facing forward, but with his head turned a bit to the left. He holds, and plays upon, a large harp. He wears tights and has his right leg drawn behind his left. His right arm is bent upward to play the harp with fingers spread. His hair is short and curly. His lips are slightly parted; he may be singing.

The figure third from the right is a young male, one of Job's sons, facing forward. He wears tights; his left leg is slightly bent and drawn behind his right, with his left foot on tiptoe. He holds and plays a curled horn with one loop in it. His right arm is bent upward to hold the horn. His hair is short.

The figure fourth from the right (and standing just right of Job) is a young female, one of Job's daughters, facing forward and to the right. She is gowned and has long hair. She holds a lyre in her left hand and plays upon its strings with the spread fingers of her right hand. Her mouth is slightly open; she may be singing. Her right arm is bent horizontally across her body.

A large flock of sheep can be seen behind the standing figures, right and left. Some of the creatures are standing and grazing; at least one is lying on the ground. Given this large flock so closely associated with the human figures, perhaps we are to think of the youthful males (and females?) as shepherds.
The foreground around the group of sheep is grassy.
A group of animals (all but one a sheep) lie in the foreground. The one exception is a dog, facing left in the center of the group. The sheep furthest to the right is a ram with looped horns.
A large tree—probably an oak—with a heavy trunk stands in the center of the design. Its dense leaves spread out along the upper reaches of the central design.

The top edge of a mountain range appears above the figures. In the sky above is a crescent moon and two stars or planets (possibly Venus, given the rising sun on the right). The sky is still dark, but a few shafts of radiance emerge from behind the trunk of the large central tree.

The top edge of a mountain range appears above the figures. The disc of the sun appears just above the mountains; its radiance and beams of light fill the sky above. Given the joyous nature of the design, this surely must be a rising (rather than setting) sun.

The outline of smoke rises from the flames (of a sacrifice?) on top of the (stone?) altar in the middle of the lower border design. The upper corners of the altar are adorned with ram's heads. A ram and shepherd's crook lie in the lower left corner of the border design; an ox or horned cow lies in the lower right corner.

component.illusobjdesc: The outlines of a tent extend up the side borders and meet in the upper border.
A cloud band bearing texts arches through the upper border design. Alternatively, these may be extensions of the smoke in the lower border design.

The cloud-like outline of smoke issues from the fire on the altar and curves below the central design. Perhaps we are to imagine that the text immediately below the central design is written on this cloud.
A (stone?) altar bearing texts stands in the middle of the lower border. Flames, perhaps of a burnt sacrifice, rise above it.
The heads (or perhaps skulls) of horned rams decorate the upper corners of the altar. Alternatively, these could be heads sculpted in stone. The heads face slightly downward.
A shepherd's crook lies in the lower left corner of the border design.
A ram, with at least one looped horn, lies prone in the lower left corner of the border design. He faces to the right. We see only its head, chest, and folded right foreleg.

An ox, or a cow with horns, lies prone in the lower right corner of the border design. The animal faces to the left, with his head turned toward the viewer. We see only its head, chest, and folded forelegs.
